transformed_texts:
Honestly, I think the Catholic Church needs to rethink some of its stances and make some changes. They've been losing followers, and I believe it's because they're not very accepting of a lot of things. They have strong views on issues like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control, which are a bit outdated in my opinion. If they were to adapt to a more modern way of thinking, they might not be worried about losing their following. Many people are starting to turn against the Catholic Church because of their views on these issues, and I think that's because they feel the Church is on the wrong side.

I mean, if you're in favor of abortion, you might not feel comfortable being part of a community that teaches it's wrong. And if you're gay or support gay marriage, you might not want to be in a community that doesn't agree with that. I don't see why the Church can't allow female priests or married priests – it's not like it would necessarily have prevented the issues they're facing. Maybe they would have done things differently, but it's hard to say.

One thing I do think the Church should reconsider is its stance on priests being allowed to be married. They say priests are married to God and devoted to their faith, but that's a pretty unique job situation. Everyone else with a job has both a career and a personal life – so, I don't see why priests can't have both too.

Honestly, I wanted to take a moment to clarify my thoughts on a sensitive topic. I've been considering this issue, and I don't think I'm opposed to the idea of gay marriage. It seems to me that a person's sexual orientation isn't something they consciously choose, it's just who they are. I think it would be unfair to hold gay people accountable for their natural inclinations.

When I think about it, it doesn't seem right that society would deny two people of the same sex the right to get married just because of their orientation. I haven't given the topic a lot of thought, but my gut feeling is that it's wrong for anyone to dictate who can and can't get married based on their sexual orientation.

It seems to me that a person's sexual orientation isn't something they can control, just like how I'm naturally straight and others are naturally gay. It's not a choice that I think they should be held accountable for.

To me, it's clear that the federal government shouldn't involve themselves in this issue. It's not really a matter of the law, and it's certainly not a moral issue in my opinion. I don't think they have the right to dictate who can and can't get married based on something as personal as their sexual orientation.

It's a sensitive topic, and I'm not sure I'm comfortable discussing it, but I do think the federal government should stay out of it. It's not their place to interfere in people's personal lives, especially when it comes to something as fundamental as who they love. It's just not something they should be involved in.

I think that gay marriage should be legalized because there's really no good reason not to. A lot of people think that same-sex couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but that's not true. It's two different things, you can't compare them. They're like two sides of the same coin - one isn't better than the other. People have the right to civil rights, such as property taxes and healthcare, which are often denied to gay couples because they're not considered 'family'. It's crazy that if you're in a gay relationship, your partner can't even be with you in the hospital or visit you if you're sick. That's pretty shallow if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone.

Scientific studies have shown that gay couples have the same rates of success and satisfaction as straight couples. It's basically the same thing - a relationship is a relationship, and that's what matters. The problem is that people get hung up on the idea that gay couples want to get married in a church, but that's not true. They just want a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. If you allow someone a civil union, why not a marriage?

It's like segregation - separate but unequal. Gay couples are treated unfairly, and it's not right. They have the same relationship dynamics, the same roles, and the same goals as straight couples. People worry about adoption and community issues, but those are separate problems. They're worried about how gay couples will affect their community, and how children of gay couples will turn out. But it's not that simple.

In New York City, for example, they have special schools for kids of gay parents because they get bullied in regular schools. It's not fair. And it shows that the real issue is not the parents, but the society we live in. Parenting skills are the same for gay and straight couples, and it's all about personal choices. The government should be involved in making gay marriage legal in every state, and the amendment should be the opposite of what it is now.

President Bush has strong views on gay marriage, which align with his views on abortion and stem cell research, but that's not a good reason to deny people their rights. Morality is subjective, and it's not okay to impose someone's morality on the rest of the country. It's hypocritical to allow some people to enforce their religious views on everyone else. People are against gay marriage because they think gay people are psychologically damaged or have a personality defect, but that's not supported by science. The American Psychological Association has disproven those claims, and it's time to listen to experts, not just popular opinion.

Okay, so one thing - I work at a hospital pharmacy during the summer. You know, people often think that just because something is illegal, it doesn't necessarily mean it doesn't have its good qualities. I mean, take it from a medical perspective. If a drug is illegal, it doesn't mean it can't be beneficial. I'm not saying it should be available to the general public, no way, that's not where I'm coming from. But for medicinal purposes, I definitely think it's a different story. We don't use illegal substances in pharmacies because they're bad, but because they have benefits that we can harness.

I mean, take oxycodone, Vicodin, and Percocets - they're controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they're beneficial. Just because there's a stigma surrounding marijuana doesn't mean we should ignore its potential benefits. I think we should be open to its advantages, not dismiss it because of its current status.

It's not like marijuana is similar to alcohol in terms of abuse potential - while abusing either substance can lead to problems, marijuana's impact is different. I think we should approach its legalization gradually, but not all at once, to prevent abuse. First, we need to get rid of the negative image surrounding marijuana. People have a skewed view of it because it's an illegal substance, but it's not as bad as heroin or cocaine. If we can change that perception, people might be more likely to use it responsibly, especially for medical purposes.

I think the church has made efforts to adapt to the modern era, becoming less strict than it used to be. Even from my own experience of attending church every Sunday as a kid, I've noticed the changes. I used to get all dressed up in cute outfits and go to a private school where I'd see my friends on the weekends. But now, especially during the summer, people show up to mass in casual beachwear, and even the morning masses are more relaxed, with people wearing jeans or khakis. It's definitely become a more casual atmosphere, which I think is a natural progression.

As for the bigger picture, I don't think allowing female priests or married priests would have prevented the problems with pedophilia in the Catholic Church. There are married individuals who still have a twisted attraction to young kids, and it's not solely because of their marital status. When someone chooses to become a priest, it's their decision, and they should consider whether they can commit to the lifestyle. Some other religions, like the Seventh-day Adventist Church, allow their clergy to be married, so it's not like it's impossible to balance faith and marriage in this way.

I think the root of the issue is that pedophilia is often an inborn trait, and it's not something people develop due to their upbringing or environment. While genetics might play a role, you can't hide it through marriage or any other means. If the church knew about the abuse and tried to cover it up, that's despicable, but I don't think that's always the case.

Overall, the church's changes haven't had a significant impact on preventing these problems. My thoughts on the matter are that it's a complex issue, and I don't have any other specific opinions about the Catholic Church beyond that.

I was initially okay with the idea, but I think that everyone was still reeling from the 9/11 attacks, and I believe that going to Iraq was partly a pretext. The Bush administration linked the war to Osama Bin Laden and 9/11, claiming Saddam Hussein had WMDs, but that turned out to be false. This whole thing bothered me, and the Iraq war really gets my blood boiling.

It seems to me that the Bush administration lied to the American people and hasn't owned up to it yet. Even Colin Powell, who presented that big UN speech, now says he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time. To me, that's a serious offense - lying to the public like that is unacceptable. The Bush administration has shown a blatant disregard for the constitution and has been working to marginalize it since 9/11. I think they had a plan to go to war from the start.

One thing that really stands out is how the younger Bush seemed to have a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein because of his dad's past dealings with him, and I think he was also hoping to expand our energy supply. That's a pretty underhanded way to do things.

I think it's time to reevaluate the situation, but withdrawing now could lead to even more problems, including a civil war that would result in more deaths. The current alternative being considered is a coalition of surrounding nations, like Syria and Saudi Arabia, to stabilize the country. However, I'm not sure that's the best idea, as it could create more problems in the long run, especially regarding Iraq's sovereignty. The country's interim government is already showing signs of breaking down, and the Parliament seems ineffective. The Prime Minister has limited control, and radical elements are vying for power, causing a lot of friction in the political process.

To be honest, I don't know how to articulate my concerns in polite conversation.

I'm still trying to process my thoughts about the War in Iraq. To be honest, it's been a bit complicated for me. I think what's making it harder is that it wasn't even officially declared as a war. It just felt like a way to get back at someone after the 9/11 attacks. I'm not really up-to-date on the details, but it seems like we're stuck over there trying to build a democracy, which is a long-term goal, and also to get access to their resources. But the thing is, it's causing a lot of problems and making people upset.

If we stay, we'll have to deal with the aftermath of trying to create a democracy, which won't happen overnight. And if we leave, they'll be mad at us for messing things up and having to start over. I'm not sure what the best approach is.

To be honest, I'm really struggling to form an opinion on this. It's a complex topic, and I don't think I fully understand it. I think we should talk more about this and get a better grasp on the situation.

I've been thinking, and I don't think we should call it a war anymore. It was never officially declared, and it's just become a way to show off our military strength. I think that's not the point of it all. It's about helping people, not just flexing our muscles.

I do think we should try to help them, but at the same time, we're wasting our resources, and it's making the President look bad. I'm not sure how much longer we can justify staying there. It's kind of like the Vietnam War – it was an undeclared war, and now it's considered a pointless war. I don't want our President to be known as the one who started a meaningless war.

It's hard to say I want the war to end, though, because there are people I know who have family members over there, and I want them to be safe. But at the same time, I don't want us to be there because it's messing with their culture and way of life. We're trying to change them into something they're not, and it's just making things worse. I think we're actually making the Al-Kaida problem worse by trying to impose our own values on them.

I think this whole thing is going to drag on for years and years, and I'm not sure what the outcome will be. I guess that's just my two cents on the matter.

Honestly, I don't think it's right for a state to declare something as legal or to make laws about it. In my opinion, that's a decision that should be left to the churches. The constitution clearly states separation of church and state, and I believe trying to enforce any form of state control over this issue would be a direct defiance of what's already been written.

I think people trying to make it illegal are essentially choosing one church's beliefs over another. As we can see, most Catholics and Christians are against it, with some areas like Boston being exceptions. I don't think it's the government's place to decide what the churches can and can't dictate as right or wrong.

The separation of church and state has been a cornerstone of the US constitution, allowing for religious tolerance. I think making an amendment to restrict this would be wrong and contradictory to what's already been said. It would be one of the few amendments that would restrict people's rights rather than the government's, and I don't believe that's right.

To me, the government should stay out of this issue altogether. I don't see why there's a push for this amendment, except that it's against the president's own personal beliefs as a Catholic. By pushing for this amendment, he's showing that he's favoring one religion over others. I think it's up to the churches to decide, not the president or anyone in government.

There doesn't seem to be any real reason for this amendment, other than personal views. I don't see how it would affect the economy, and it could potentially have a positive impact on society. In the end, I've said what I think, and I don't think there's anything more to add.

Okay, let's start from the beginning - I think the US government was not completely transparent about the reasons for invading Iraq, and I believe they tried to link the invasion to the 9/11 attacks in a way that wasn't entirely justified. The government played on the emotions of the American people, using their outrage over the 9/11 attacks to justify the invasion in 2003. Personally, I'm against war, especially preemptive strikes, and I think the invasion of Iraq was a repeat of some of the mistakes made in the Vietnam War.

A huge number of American soldiers have died in the war, which is absolutely heartbreaking. The American government didn't seem to be prepared for the aftermath of removing the Iraqi government and the power vacuum that followed. They were trying to establish a democratic government, but it's a complex and difficult process that takes years, as we saw in our own country's struggle for democracy.

The US government made it seem like the transition would be smooth and easy, but it's been a long and hard ordeal. We're still in Iraq, and it's been almost the year 2007, with many American troops still dying, and we're still trying to train the Iraqi military and police to take control of their own country. I think the government was naive to think it would be a short and successful stay, and they tried to deceive the American people into believing that.

It's a difficult decision to make to continue the war, especially when we've been there for so long. Once you're in, it's hard to just leave, especially since we're the ones who took away their government and way of life. However, it's also hard to keep risking the lives of American soldiers for what seems like an endless war. The real reason we're focusing on Iraq, I think, is because of the significant oil resources there and the desire to control them.

I'm also concerned that the US government isn't being thorough enough or truthful enough in making their decisions. They claimed Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but none were ever found, and yet we're not taking action against other countries with known WMDs, like North Korea. I just hope the war ends soon and there's peace in Iraq, but it seems unlikely.

Okay, let's see... I'm all for gay marriage; I've always been. I genuinely believe it's a matter of personal preference, and research has increasingly shown that it's biological rather than a product of social influences. I think it's inhumane to deny people rights due to something that's not within their control. I've always been an advocate for gay marriage.

I don't think governments or politics should have a say in this; it's a deeply personal issue that affects individuals and their households. Take my neighborhood, for instance, where there are a few openly gay couples living together. They function just like any other family, and it's hard to see why their relationships should be treated differently. I find it ridiculous that politicians like Bush would try to dictate what marriage means and interpret it according to their own whims.

From what I've read and heard from various sources, there's evidence that being gay may be linked to a chemical imbalance in the brain, rather than being a result of upbringing or environment. For example, if someone grows up with four sisters and no father figure, that doesn't necessarily determine their sexual orientation.

In any case, it seems that if a straight couple wants to get married, they can do it discreetly, without drawing attention to themselves. However, if two gay people want to get married, it becomes a major public spectacle, splashed across the front pages of newspapers like the New York Times. I think marriage should be a private, personal matter, not something that's subject to public scrutiny and national attention.

Honestly, when you post something online, it's out there for everyone to see. As an R.A., I've dealt with this before. Once you put something on the internet, you can't take it back. It influences how people perceive you, especially if you're discussing sensitive topics like violence or shootings. It's only a matter of time before someone sees it and shares it. Since the internet is public domain, even if it's a private profile, your friends on Myspace will receive the bulletin. In this case, it wasn't the school that received it, but someone who was concerned enough to report it. The school can't just ignore it, as they have a responsibility to act on potential threats to ensure everyone's safety. 

I understand that some people might just be joking around, but it's hard to tell what's a joke and what's not. It's like that situation we had at school, where someone overheard a comment and reported it. The person's friend checked their Facebook and was worried about some posts that might have been meant as a joke but took on a more serious tone. When you post something online, you're essentially giving up your right to privacy. If you don't want it out there, don't post it. You can't control what others think or how they react to it. While I think it's a bad idea for school officials to be friends with their students on social media, if something is brought to their attention, they can't just ignore it. It's not an invasion of privacy if someone you've given access to your online profile reports something that could pose a threat. If it's a genuine concern, they have to take it seriously.

I also believe that teachers shouldn't create fake social media accounts to keep an eye on their students. That's just not their place. As an R.A., I wouldn't friend my residents on social media because I don't want to know about their personal lives, especially if they're posting about activities I'm not supposed to be aware of. I don't want that kind of responsibility or the potential conflict that comes with it.

I feel like this war has been dragging on for far too long. Initially, I believed the goal was commendable – to bring democracy to a country in need. However, it seems we've lost sight of that objective and are now fighting for our own sake, proving our status as a world power. The original motivation, tied to George Bush's past conflicts with Saddam Hussein, raises questions about its validity. If the intention was genuinely to introduce democracy to a nation lacking a fair system, that would be a justifiable reason, but I'm not convinced that's the case.

I think we made our point clear in the early stages of the war – it was a statement in itself. But the prolonged duration, spanning over a year and more, is excessive. If our original goal was to liberate a country from tyranny, that's a noble cause. However, over time, our reasons have become distorted and misconceived, with it seeming that we're fighting just to be at war.

I do believe it's time to bring this to an end. The Iraqi government will eventually have to fend for themselves; our continued involvement is draining our economy, with billions of dollars being spent on a war that's lost its purpose. We have our own domestic issues to address, like poverty, public roads, and healthcare, which could be better funded with the money we're spending on this conflict. It's disheartening to see our citizens being killed in a war that's no longer serving its intended purpose.

I was wondering if I could get a clarification on something, but I guess it's kind of a complex issue. It was prevented because someone went online and found that there was like a certain situation. I'm not sure if that's an invasion of privacy, but I think it's worth exploring. On sites like Myspace, if you post information, it's pretty much available for everyone to see. You have to be a member to access someone's profile, but if you've accepted them as a friend, you're essentially giving them permission to see your stuff. It's the same with any information you put online - you have to be aware that lots of people will see it. In this case, I think it's a good thing that someone saw that info and was able to prevent something bad from happening.

However, I can see why it might be tough to have someone constantly monitoring people's profiles, especially if it's discriminatory. It's not right to single out certain individuals, and it's not feasible to have someone's job be to browse through everyone's profiles. It really depends on the situation - were they just randomly looking or were they actively searching for something? I'm not sure.

Personally, I have a Facebook account, and it bothers me that there are creepy people out there who can see my stuff. I've seen a documentary about someone who showed how easy it is to get information online, and it was pretty disturbing. They were able to get a girl's screen name and meet with her in under a minute. It's hard because you think you're safe, but you're not. I've had people from my classes IM me, even though they don't know my real name. They know what I look like, my interests, and even my class schedule. I try to limit what I put online, but it's a tricky balance between keeping it private and being able to communicate with friends.

I was talking to my roommate about this, and she told me about a situation in her high school where students were banned from having Myspace. I'm not sure how the school officials had the power to do that, and it seems like a privacy issue to me. I don't know if I agree with it, but it's definitely an interesting topic to consider.

I'm thinking about the Iraq War, and I'm hesitant to express my opinion because I feel like I'm just jumping on a bandwagon.  However, my initial stance against the war still stands, and I'm not just following the crowd. 

The fact that most of the world shares my opinion is undeniable.  Polls have consistently shown that around seventy-five to eighty percent of people worldwide believe that the war was a mistake.  This includes a significant portion of US troops stationed in Iraq, who think it's a bad idea and want us to withdraw within a year.  It's clear that the situation has been a disaster from the beginning, and we're struggling to find a way out.

The cultural differences between the US and Middle Eastern countries seem to be a significant obstacle.  We have a vastly different understanding of how to govern and live in a society, and trying to impose our system on them isn't working out.  I think it's naive to believe that we can bring democracy to a region where it's not wanted.  Saddam Hussein was certainly a bad guy, but we need to consider the pros and cons before invading a country that's likely to turn into a quagmire.

To be honest, I don't see a reason to stay in Iraq any longer than necessary.  I'm not buying into the administration's ideas about why we should stay, and I haven't heard a convincing argument for it.  If they want to withdraw gradually over the course of a year or more, I'd be okay with that, but I don't see why we can't just leave now.  It's worth noting that a significant portion of Iraqis think we should be gone within the year, and even more think we should leave immediately.  These are the people we're trying to help, and their opinions should carry some weight.

If we asked them if we should stay, and they said no, it would be hard to argue with their decision.  If things go wrong after we leave, we can at least say that it was their decision, not ours.  If we choose to help them after that, we might be seen as the good guys, but let's be realistic – we'll never be seen as heroes in the Middle East.  All we can do is try to minimize the damage and get out as soon as possible.

I completely agree that gender discrimination is still a significant issue in the United States. It's not just limited to women, though - certain industries and societal norms can make it tough for both men and women to succeed. In many careers, women face a 'glass ceiling' where, despite being qualified, they're overlooked for promotions due to historical biases. This isn't unique to women, though; men in non-traditional roles like stay-at-home dads also face prejudice. People often assume men should be the primary breadwinners, and those who choose to stay home are judged for it. Similarly, in the fashion industry, men who are genuinely interested in fashion are often taken less seriously because their interests don't fit traditional male stereotypes. 

This slow change is partly due to the deeply ingrained mindset in society. Although we've made significant progress since the 1800s, it's still a long way to go. However, I believe we're moving in the right direction. Women are breaking through glass ceilings and becoming CEOs, and people are becoming more accepting of stay-at-home dads. As a result, we're starting to see a shift in how we view these non-traditional roles. To promote further change, we need to showcase the qualities and strengths of individuals who are often stereotyped against. Rather than forcing it, which can lead to resistance, we should highlight their capabilities in a subtle yet effective way. I think we're at a good point where we're starting to see the importance of promoting diversity and inclusion. 

It's also worth noting that people from different backgrounds and regions can face discrimination based on their upbringing, education, or accent. For instance, someone from a rural area with a non-traditional education background might be judged by those with more 'refined' speech or education. This is another example of how various factors can contribute to discrimination, not just gender. 

I'm not sure if there's anything more we can do that hasn't already been done. If we push too hard for change, people might resist, and progress would be slowed. We need to find a balance between promoting equality and respecting people's differences. Our slow but steady progress is a step in the right direction, and I'm hopeful that we'll continue to move forward.

I think it's been clarified that marijuana wasn't fully legalized, but rather decriminalized. This means it's no longer considered a criminal offense, but more like a traffic ticket. If someone gets caught and cited, it's unlikely to have severe consequences in the long run, especially when it comes to things like job interviews. However, even with decriminalization, there are still concerns about the potential repercussions, which can be a major worry for many people.

On the other hand, there's a valid argument that arresting people for marijuana possession is costly for cities, from the initial arrest to court appearances and public defenders. This can be a significant financial burden, especially for municipalities struggling financially. Even so, some cities are hesitant to make this change, even if it could free up funds for more important community programs.

Denver, however, is a different story. Given its more open-minded and progressive attitude, I think it's perfectly fine that they've decriminalized marijuana. The extra funding can be used for things like public education, social programs for seniors, and food programs for the homeless. It's not a straightforward decision, as there are valid reasons to be cautious about marijuana being everywhere, but there's also a financial aspect to consider.

If marijuana were fully legalized, it's possible that it could become as prevalent as cigarettes, which could lead to people smoking and driving, and other issues. It's still a bit taboo in many places, so having it out in the open might be awkward for some people. While I'm not sure what I would think about that, I do know that marijuana can have different effects on people, just like alcohol. Some people can handle it better than others, and it's hard to generalize how people will react.

I think both marijuana and alcohol have their own negative effects, and it's essential to acknowledge that people respond differently to substances. Some people can be more moderate, while others might not be able to control their consumption. It's a complex issue, but I do believe that both substances have their own unique consequences.

To be honest, I'd say yes to making some changes because a lot of the practices are quite traditional. They've stuck to the same methods for a long time, and it's good to have roots in tradition. However, it's also crucial to be adaptable to change. Sometimes, I feel like the Catholic Church can be quite rigid in its expectations and doesn't accept people who don't live up to their doctrine perfectly. They also tend to be quite exclusive when it comes to people from other religions, like my parents, who are Episcopalians. They refused to let my parents get married in the Catholic Church because of my dad's background.

This isn't exactly what you'd call being tolerant of other faiths. We're taught to love others, which is a fundamental Catholic teaching, but it's hypocritical to say that and not practice it. I think the Catholic Church's doctrine often conflicts with its practices, which can be quite outdated. They stick to their traditional ways even when they're no longer relevant.

I don't think my personal views would necessarily change the situation, but personally, I think it would be a good idea for priests to be allowed to get married. However, I'm not convinced that this would deter priests who engage in pedophilic behavior. It's a different issue altogether, and people who would do such things would probably do so regardless of their marital status.

It's worth noting that people who abuse children tend to do so because of the power imbalance, not because of their marital status. Allowing priests to be married wouldn't necessarily stop these kinds of incidents from happening. It's unlikely that this would make a significant difference.

Honestly, I'm still trying to figure out where I stand on this issue, and I'm not sure if there's a right or wrong side to take. What I do know is that this is one of the most challenging topics we're dealing with right now. The line between separating church and state is a delicate one, and defining marriage is a sensitive matter that can be tricky to navigate without offending anyone. 

I'm thinking that maybe we should look at all civil unions as just that – a union between two people, without the government looking into whether it was a religious or secular ceremony. I mean, if it's just about two people coming together, then why should the government care what kind of marriage it is? It's about the bond between the individuals, not about what the government thinks of it. 

The thing is, if gay marriage is seen as just another type of civil union, then it shouldn't be a problem. It's all about two people coming together, and that's what counts. If all the states can come to a logical agreement, then it would be great if we could push for it to become federal law. But trying to ban gay marriage through a constitutional amendment is extreme – it's not the kind of thing that should be decided by amending the constitution.

I just don't think it's worth altering the constitution for a cause that's not big enough. It's a serious issue for some people, but it's not something that should warrant changing the foundation of our country. It's just not that important to define and ban gay marriage by amending the constitution. Let's keep it simple – it's about two people coming together. 

I don't know, but that's my two cents on the matter.

I grew up in a Christian household, where things got a bit hazy when it came to homosexuality. Having lots of gay friends made me think a lot about this issue, and I didn't necessarily agree with the lifestyle, but I do think it should be legalized. I think it's crazy to make it a national issue, and instead, each state should have its own say. It's like, some states are super liberal and others are more conservative, so I don't think the president should impose their views on everyone. If you live in a state that's liberal, you know how they feel about it, and if you don't like it, maybe you shouldn't move there. I think everyone should have the same opportunities, so it should be up to each state to decide. I already kind of said that, but yeah. I don't think it's right that Bush can decide for the whole country that gay marriage is against the law. He shouldn't get to dictate how each state runs itself. I mean, he's not gonna be in office forever, and if a new president comes in and thinks differently, the ban will just be lifted and then put back on again. It's simpler to just let each state decide for themselves, since they're the ones who have to live with the consequences.

Okay, let me start again. I don't agree with the idea that the school acted unreasonably. I was thinking about this, and it seems like the school's actions might have been justified. Myspace is a public platform, and anything posted there can be seen by anyone, including school officials. Even if the post wasn't made under the school's name, officials could still access it from their homes. If going through Myspace can prevent a school shooting, which is the school's responsibility, then I think it's perfectly fine.

It's like when school officials check Myspace to monitor student behavior, like whether they're drinking or smoking. They're doing it to catch students and get them in trouble, which I think is an invasion of privacy. However, if it saves lives or makes the school a safer place, I don't see it as an invasion at all. It's a bit like if they searched homes to prevent a school shooting; it's all about keeping students safe.

It's a lot easier to express myself when writing, but I guess what I'm trying to say is that posting on Myspace is a public thing, and students shouldn't be surprised if they get in trouble. I'm cautious about posting stuff online, even emails, because you never know who might see it. If you do something on Myspace, you have to be prepared for the consequences. It's not an invasion of privacy if the school officials can see it because it's a public platform.

If you do something wrong in college and grow up to be an important person, an old email can still come back to haunt you. Once something is on the internet, it's there forever, and you can't take it back. It's not an invasion of privacy if the school officials are doing it to make the school safer. I've talked to a teacher about this, and they said that they have to ensure the school is safe, like during lockdowns and drills.

In this case, the school officials were just trying to make the school a safer place, which is their responsibility. They were preventing something bad from happening, like a school shooting. So, I think they acted reasonably. That's all I have to say on the matter.

Okay, I've been thinking a lot about the war and our involvement in it. To be honest, my initial reaction was to support it after 9/11, which had a huge impact on me personally. I thought we should take action and show them the same level of devastation they brought to us. However, over time, I've come to realize that we jumped into this without a clear plan or understanding of the long-term consequences. 

Unfortunately, I think that's exactly what led to our problems. When emotions are running high, we tend to overlook the bigger picture. We went in there unprepared, not knowing what to expect, and that's exactly what backfired on us. 

To be frank, I've lost interest in the whole situation. As long as the people over there are fighting among themselves, they won't be able to focus on fighting us. It's quite evident that we're not making a difference; they're too busy infighting to care about us. Sometimes it feels like they're not even human, the way they conduct war. It's savage and brutal, and I don't think they're fighting for the betterment of their country – they just want us out.

I think we should've taken a step back and thought this through before getting involved. We were driven by a desire for revenge, and President Bush declared war on Iraq largely in response to public sentiment. At the time, I understood his position, but now I believe we could've handled it differently. We were too focused on the immediate aftermath of 9/11, and we didn't have a clear plan for what we wanted to achieve in Iraq. 

If we had unified our goals and strategies, we might have avoided some of the chaos we're seeing today. But that wasn't the case, and now I think we're stuck in a situation that's not working for us. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones who can change the people of Iraq; they're too entrenched in their ways, and we'll never be able to bring about lasting change.

As it stands, I don't think we're making enough progress to justify our continued presence in Iraq. We've achieved some things, but not enough to justify the costs. Once we leave, the situation will likely collapse, and we'll just be hurting ourselves by staying any longer. It's time to reassess our involvement and consider pulling out. That's my two cents on the matter.

transformed_texts:
Honestly, I think the Catholic Church needs to rethink some of its stances and make some changes. They've been losing followers, and I believe it's because they're not very accepting of a lot of things. They have strong views on issues like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control, which are a bit outdated in my opinion. If they were to adapt to a more modern way of thinking, they might not be worried about losing their following. Many people are starting to turn against the Catholic Church because of their views on these issues, and I think that's because they feel the Church is on the wrong side.

I mean, if you're in favor of abortion, you might not feel comfortable being part of a community that teaches it's wrong. And if you're gay or support gay marriage, you might not want to be in a community that doesn't agree with that. I don't see why the Church can't allow female priests or married priests – it's not like it would necessarily have prevented the issues they're facing. Maybe they would have done things differently, but it's hard to say.

One thing I do think the Church should reconsider is its stance on priests being allowed to be married. They say priests are married to God and devoted to their faith, but that's a pretty unique job situation. Everyone else with a job has both a career and a personal life – so, I don't see why priests can't have both too.

Honestly, I wanted to take a moment to clarify my thoughts on a sensitive topic. I've been considering this issue, and I don't think I'm opposed to the idea of gay marriage. It seems to me that a person's sexual orientation isn't something they consciously choose, it's just who they are. I think it would be unfair to hold gay people accountable for their natural inclinations.

When I think about it, it doesn't seem right that society would deny two people of the same sex the right to get married just because of their orientation. I haven't given the topic a lot of thought, but my gut feeling is that it's wrong for anyone to dictate who can and can't get married based on their sexual orientation.

It seems to me that a person's sexual orientation isn't something they can control, just like how I'm naturally straight and others are naturally gay. It's not a choice that I think they should be held accountable for.

To me, it's clear that the federal government shouldn't involve themselves in this issue. It's not really a matter of the law, and it's certainly not a moral issue in my opinion. I don't think they have the right to dictate who can and can't get married based on something as personal as their sexual orientation.

It's a sensitive topic, and I'm not sure I'm comfortable discussing it, but I do think the federal government should stay out of it. It's not their place to interfere in people's personal lives, especially when it comes to something as fundamental as who they love. It's just not something they should be involved in.

I think that gay marriage should be legalized because there's really no good reason not to. A lot of people think that same-sex couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but that's not true. It's two different things, you can't compare them. They're like two sides of the same coin - one isn't better than the other. People have the right to civil rights, such as property taxes and healthcare, which are often denied to gay couples because they're not considered 'family'. It's crazy that if you're in a gay relationship, your partner can't even be with you in the hospital or visit you if you're sick. That's pretty shallow if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone.

Scientific studies have shown that gay couples have the same rates of success and satisfaction as straight couples. It's basically the same thing - a relationship is a relationship, and that's what matters. The problem is that people get hung up on the idea that gay couples want to get married in a church, but that's not true. They just want a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. If you allow someone a civil union, why not a marriage?

It's like segregation - separate but unequal. Gay couples are treated unfairly, and it's not right. They have the same relationship dynamics, the same roles, and the same goals as straight couples. People worry about adoption and community issues, but those are separate problems. They're worried about how gay couples will affect their community, and how children of gay couples will turn out. But it's not that simple.

In New York City, for example, they have special schools for kids of gay parents because they get bullied in regular schools. It's not fair. And it shows that the real issue is not the parents, but the society we live in. Parenting skills are the same for gay and straight couples, and it's all about personal choices. The government should be involved in making gay marriage legal in every state, and the amendment should be the opposite of what it is now.

President Bush has strong views on gay marriage, which align with his views on abortion and stem cell research, but that's not a good reason to deny people their rights. Morality is subjective, and it's not okay to impose someone's morality on the rest of the country. It's hypocritical to allow some people to enforce their religious views on everyone else. People are against gay marriage because they think gay people are psychologically damaged or have a personality defect, but that's not supported by science. The American Psychological Association has disproven those claims, and it's time to listen to experts, not just popular opinion.

Okay, so one thing - I work at a hospital pharmacy during the summer. You know, people often think that just because something is illegal, it doesn't necessarily mean it doesn't have its good qualities. I mean, take it from a medical perspective. If a drug is illegal, it doesn't mean it can't be beneficial. I'm not saying it should be available to the general public, no way, that's not where I'm coming from. But for medicinal purposes, I definitely think it's a different story. We don't use illegal substances in pharmacies because they're bad, but because they have benefits that we can harness.

I mean, take oxycodone, Vicodin, and Percocets - they're controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they're beneficial. Just because there's a stigma surrounding marijuana doesn't mean we should ignore its potential benefits. I think we should be open to its advantages, not dismiss it because of its current status.

It's not like marijuana is similar to alcohol in terms of abuse potential - while abusing either substance can lead to problems, marijuana's impact is different. I think we should approach its legalization gradually, but not all at once, to prevent abuse. First, we need to get rid of the negative image surrounding marijuana. People have a skewed view of it because it's an illegal substance, but it's not as bad as heroin or cocaine. If we can change that perception, people might be more likely to use it responsibly, especially for medical purposes.

I think the church has made efforts to adapt to the modern era, becoming less strict than it used to be. Even from my own experience of attending church every Sunday as a kid, I've noticed the changes. I used to get all dressed up in cute outfits and go to a private school where I'd see my friends on the weekends. But now, especially during the summer, people show up to mass in casual beachwear, and even the morning masses are more relaxed, with people wearing jeans or khakis. It's definitely become a more casual atmosphere, which I think is a natural progression.

As for the bigger picture, I don't think allowing female priests or married priests would have prevented the problems with pedophilia in the Catholic Church. There are married individuals who still have a twisted attraction to young kids, and it's not solely because of their marital status. When someone chooses to become a priest, it's their decision, and they should consider whether they can commit to the lifestyle. Some other religions, like the Seventh-day Adventist Church, allow their clergy to be married, so it's not like it's impossible to balance faith and marriage in this way.

I think the root of the issue is that pedophilia is often an inborn trait, and it's not something people develop due to their upbringing or environment. While genetics might play a role, you can't hide it through marriage or any other means. If the church knew about the abuse and tried to cover it up, that's despicable, but I don't think that's always the case.

Overall, the church's changes haven't had a significant impact on preventing these problems. My thoughts on the matter are that it's a complex issue, and I don't have any other specific opinions about the Catholic Church beyond that.

I was initially okay with the idea, but I think that everyone was still reeling from the 9/11 attacks, and I believe that going to Iraq was partly a pretext. The Bush administration linked the war to Osama Bin Laden and 9/11, claiming Saddam Hussein had WMDs, but that turned out to be false. This whole thing bothered me, and the Iraq war really gets my blood boiling.

It seems to me that the Bush administration lied to the American people and hasn't owned up to it yet. Even Colin Powell, who presented that big UN speech, now says he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time. To me, that's a serious offense - lying to the public like that is unacceptable. The Bush administration has shown a blatant disregard for the constitution and has been working to marginalize it since 9/11. I think they had a plan to go to war from the start.

One thing that really stands out is how the younger Bush seemed to have a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein because of his dad's past dealings with him, and I think he was also hoping to expand our energy supply. That's a pretty underhanded way to do things.

I think it's time to reevaluate the situation, but withdrawing now could lead to even more problems, including a civil war that would result in more deaths. The current alternative being considered is a coalition of surrounding nations, like Syria and Saudi Arabia, to stabilize the country. However, I'm not sure that's the best idea, as it could create more problems in the long run, especially regarding Iraq's sovereignty. The country's interim government is already showing signs of breaking down, and the Parliament seems ineffective. The Prime Minister has limited control, and radical elements are vying for power, causing a lot of friction in the political process.

To be honest, I don't know how to articulate my concerns in polite conversation.

I'm still trying to process my thoughts about the War in Iraq. To be honest, it's been a bit complicated for me. I think what's making it harder is that it wasn't even officially declared as a war. It just felt like a way to get back at someone after the 9/11 attacks. I'm not really up-to-date on the details, but it seems like we're stuck over there trying to build a democracy, which is a long-term goal, and also to get access to their resources. But the thing is, it's causing a lot of problems and making people upset.

If we stay, we'll have to deal with the aftermath of trying to create a democracy, which won't happen overnight. And if we leave, they'll be mad at us for messing things up and having to start over. I'm not sure what the best approach is.

To be honest, I'm really struggling to form an opinion on this. It's a complex topic, and I don't think I fully understand it. I think we should talk more about this and get a better grasp on the situation.

I've been thinking, and I don't think we should call it a war anymore. It was never officially declared, and it's just become a way to show off our military strength. I think that's not the point of it all. It's about helping people, not just flexing our muscles.

I do think we should try to help them, but at the same time, we're wasting our resources, and it's making the President look bad. I'm not sure how much longer we can justify staying there. It's kind of like the Vietnam War – it was an undeclared war, and now it's considered a pointless war. I don't want our President to be known as the one who started a meaningless war.

It's hard to say I want the war to end, though, because there are people I know who have family members over there, and I want them to be safe. But at the same time, I don't want us to be there because it's messing with their culture and way of life. We're trying to change them into something they're not, and it's just making things worse. I think we're actually making the Al-Kaida problem worse by trying to impose our own values on them.

I think this whole thing is going to drag on for years and years, and I'm not sure what the outcome will be. I guess that's just my two cents on the matter.

Honestly, I don't think it's right for a state to declare something as legal or to make laws about it. In my opinion, that's a decision that should be left to the churches. The constitution clearly states separation of church and state, and I believe trying to enforce any form of state control over this issue would be a direct defiance of what's already been written.

I think people trying to make it illegal are essentially choosing one church's beliefs over another. As we can see, most Catholics and Christians are against it, with some areas like Boston being exceptions. I don't think it's the government's place to decide what the churches can and can't dictate as right or wrong.

The separation of church and state has been a cornerstone of the US constitution, allowing for religious tolerance. I think making an amendment to restrict this would be wrong and contradictory to what's already been said. It would be one of the few amendments that would restrict people's rights rather than the government's, and I don't believe that's right.

To me, the government should stay out of this issue altogether. I don't see why there's a push for this amendment, except that it's against the president's own personal beliefs as a Catholic. By pushing for this amendment, he's showing that he's favoring one religion over others. I think it's up to the churches to decide, not the president or anyone in government.

There doesn't seem to be any real reason for this amendment, other than personal views. I don't see how it would affect the economy, and it could potentially have a positive impact on society. In the end, I've said what I think, and I don't think there's anything more to add.

Okay, let's start from the beginning - I think the US government was not completely transparent about the reasons for invading Iraq, and I believe they tried to link the invasion to the 9/11 attacks in a way that wasn't entirely justified. The government played on the emotions of the American people, using their outrage over the 9/11 attacks to justify the invasion in 2003. Personally, I'm against war, especially preemptive strikes, and I think the invasion of Iraq was a repeat of some of the mistakes made in the Vietnam War.

A huge number of American soldiers have died in the war, which is absolutely heartbreaking. The American government didn't seem to be prepared for the aftermath of removing the Iraqi government and the power vacuum that followed. They were trying to establish a democratic government, but it's a complex and difficult process that takes years, as we saw in our own country's struggle for democracy.

The US government made it seem like the transition would be smooth and easy, but it's been a long and hard ordeal. We're still in Iraq, and it's been almost the year 2007, with many American troops still dying, and we're still trying to train the Iraqi military and police to take control of their own country. I think the government was naive to think it would be a short and successful stay, and they tried to deceive the American people into believing that.

It's a difficult decision to make to continue the war, especially when we've been there for so long. Once you're in, it's hard to just leave, especially since we're the ones who took away their government and way of life. However, it's also hard to keep risking the lives of American soldiers for what seems like an endless war. The real reason we're focusing on Iraq, I think, is because of the significant oil resources there and the desire to control them.

I'm also concerned that the US government isn't being thorough enough or truthful enough in making their decisions. They claimed Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but none were ever found, and yet we're not taking action against other countries with known WMDs, like North Korea. I just hope the war ends soon and there's peace in Iraq, but it seems unlikely.

Okay, let's see... I'm all for gay marriage; I've always been. I genuinely believe it's a matter of personal preference, and research has increasingly shown that it's biological rather than a product of social influences. I think it's inhumane to deny people rights due to something that's not within their control. I've always been an advocate for gay marriage.

I don't think governments or politics should have a say in this; it's a deeply personal issue that affects individuals and their households. Take my neighborhood, for instance, where there are a few openly gay couples living together. They function just like any other family, and it's hard to see why their relationships should be treated differently. I find it ridiculous that politicians like Bush would try to dictate what marriage means and interpret it according to their own whims.

From what I've read and heard from various sources, there's evidence that being gay may be linked to a chemical imbalance in the brain, rather than being a result of upbringing or environment. For example, if someone grows up with four sisters and no father figure, that doesn't necessarily determine their sexual orientation.

In any case, it seems that if a straight couple wants to get married, they can do it discreetly, without drawing attention to themselves. However, if two gay people want to get married, it becomes a major public spectacle, splashed across the front pages of newspapers like the New York Times. I think marriage should be a private, personal matter, not something that's subject to public scrutiny and national attention.

Honestly, when you post something online, it's out there for everyone to see. As an R.A., I've dealt with this before. Once you put something on the internet, you can't take it back. It influences how people perceive you, especially if you're discussing sensitive topics like violence or shootings. It's only a matter of time before someone sees it and shares it. Since the internet is public domain, even if it's a private profile, your friends on Myspace will receive the bulletin. In this case, it wasn't the school that received it, but someone who was concerned enough to report it. The school can't just ignore it, as they have a responsibility to act on potential threats to ensure everyone's safety. 

I understand that some people might just be joking around, but it's hard to tell what's a joke and what's not. It's like that situation we had at school, where someone overheard a comment and reported it. The person's friend checked their Facebook and was worried about some posts that might have been meant as a joke but took on a more serious tone. When you post something online, you're essentially giving up your right to privacy. If you don't want it out there, don't post it. You can't control what others think or how they react to it. While I think it's a bad idea for school officials to be friends with their students on social media, if something is brought to their attention, they can't just ignore it. It's not an invasion of privacy if someone you've given access to your online profile reports something that could pose a threat. If it's a genuine concern, they have to take it seriously.

I also believe that teachers shouldn't create fake social media accounts to keep an eye on their students. That's just not their place. As an R.A., I wouldn't friend my residents on social media because I don't want to know about their personal lives, especially if they're posting about activities I'm not supposed to be aware of. I don't want that kind of responsibility or the potential conflict that comes with it.

I feel like this war has been dragging on for far too long. Initially, I believed the goal was commendable – to bring democracy to a country in need. However, it seems we've lost sight of that objective and are now fighting for our own sake, proving our status as a world power. The original motivation, tied to George Bush's past conflicts with Saddam Hussein, raises questions about its validity. If the intention was genuinely to introduce democracy to a nation lacking a fair system, that would be a justifiable reason, but I'm not convinced that's the case.

I think we made our point clear in the early stages of the war – it was a statement in itself. But the prolonged duration, spanning over a year and more, is excessive. If our original goal was to liberate a country from tyranny, that's a noble cause. However, over time, our reasons have become distorted and misconceived, with it seeming that we're fighting just to be at war.

I do believe it's time to bring this to an end. The Iraqi government will eventually have to fend for themselves; our continued involvement is draining our economy, with billions of dollars being spent on a war that's lost its purpose. We have our own domestic issues to address, like poverty, public roads, and healthcare, which could be better funded with the money we're spending on this conflict. It's disheartening to see our citizens being killed in a war that's no longer serving its intended purpose.

I was wondering if I could get a clarification on something, but I guess it's kind of a complex issue. It was prevented because someone went online and found that there was like a certain situation. I'm not sure if that's an invasion of privacy, but I think it's worth exploring. On sites like Myspace, if you post information, it's pretty much available for everyone to see. You have to be a member to access someone's profile, but if you've accepted them as a friend, you're essentially giving them permission to see your stuff. It's the same with any information you put online - you have to be aware that lots of people will see it. In this case, I think it's a good thing that someone saw that info and was able to prevent something bad from happening.

However, I can see why it might be tough to have someone constantly monitoring people's profiles, especially if it's discriminatory. It's not right to single out certain individuals, and it's not feasible to have someone's job be to browse through everyone's profiles. It really depends on the situation - were they just randomly looking or were they actively searching for something? I'm not sure.

Personally, I have a Facebook account, and it bothers me that there are creepy people out there who can see my stuff. I've seen a documentary about someone who showed how easy it is to get information online, and it was pretty disturbing. They were able to get a girl's screen name and meet with her in under a minute. It's hard because you think you're safe, but you're not. I've had people from my classes IM me, even though they don't know my real name. They know what I look like, my interests, and even my class schedule. I try to limit what I put online, but it's a tricky balance between keeping it private and being able to communicate with friends.

I was talking to my roommate about this, and she told me about a situation in her high school where students were banned from having Myspace. I'm not sure how the school officials had the power to do that, and it seems like a privacy issue to me. I don't know if I agree with it, but it's definitely an interesting topic to consider.

I'm thinking about the Iraq War, and I'm hesitant to express my opinion because I feel like I'm just jumping on a bandwagon.  However, my initial stance against the war still stands, and I'm not just following the crowd. 

The fact that most of the world shares my opinion is undeniable.  Polls have consistently shown that around seventy-five to eighty percent of people worldwide believe that the war was a mistake.  This includes a significant portion of US troops stationed in Iraq, who think it's a bad idea and want us to withdraw within a year.  It's clear that the situation has been a disaster from the beginning, and we're struggling to find a way out.

The cultural differences between the US and Middle Eastern countries seem to be a significant obstacle.  We have a vastly different understanding of how to govern and live in a society, and trying to impose our system on them isn't working out.  I think it's naive to believe that we can bring democracy to a region where it's not wanted.  Saddam Hussein was certainly a bad guy, but we need to consider the pros and cons before invading a country that's likely to turn into a quagmire.

To be honest, I don't see a reason to stay in Iraq any longer than necessary.  I'm not buying into the administration's ideas about why we should stay, and I haven't heard a convincing argument for it.  If they want to withdraw gradually over the course of a year or more, I'd be okay with that, but I don't see why we can't just leave now.  It's worth noting that a significant portion of Iraqis think we should be gone within the year, and even more think we should leave immediately.  These are the people we're trying to help, and their opinions should carry some weight.

If we asked them if we should stay, and they said no, it would be hard to argue with their decision.  If things go wrong after we leave, we can at least say that it was their decision, not ours.  If we choose to help them after that, we might be seen as the good guys, but let's be realistic – we'll never be seen as heroes in the Middle East.  All we can do is try to minimize the damage and get out as soon as possible.

I completely agree that gender discrimination is still a significant issue in the United States. It's not just limited to women, though - certain industries and societal norms can make it tough for both men and women to succeed. In many careers, women face a 'glass ceiling' where, despite being qualified, they're overlooked for promotions due to historical biases. This isn't unique to women, though; men in non-traditional roles like stay-at-home dads also face prejudice. People often assume men should be the primary breadwinners, and those who choose to stay home are judged for it. Similarly, in the fashion industry, men who are genuinely interested in fashion are often taken less seriously because their interests don't fit traditional male stereotypes. 

This slow change is partly due to the deeply ingrained mindset in society. Although we've made significant progress since the 1800s, it's still a long way to go. However, I believe we're moving in the right direction. Women are breaking through glass ceilings and becoming CEOs, and people are becoming more accepting of stay-at-home dads. As a result, we're starting to see a shift in how we view these non-traditional roles. To promote further change, we need to showcase the qualities and strengths of individuals who are often stereotyped against. Rather than forcing it, which can lead to resistance, we should highlight their capabilities in a subtle yet effective way. I think we're at a good point where we're starting to see the importance of promoting diversity and inclusion. 

It's also worth noting that people from different backgrounds and regions can face discrimination based on their upbringing, education, or accent. For instance, someone from a rural area with a non-traditional education background might be judged by those with more 'refined' speech or education. This is another example of how various factors can contribute to discrimination, not just gender. 

I'm not sure if there's anything more we can do that hasn't already been done. If we push too hard for change, people might resist, and progress would be slowed. We need to find a balance between promoting equality and respecting people's differences. Our slow but steady progress is a step in the right direction, and I'm hopeful that we'll continue to move forward.

I think it's been clarified that marijuana wasn't fully legalized, but rather decriminalized. This means it's no longer considered a criminal offense, but more like a traffic ticket. If someone gets caught and cited, it's unlikely to have severe consequences in the long run, especially when it comes to things like job interviews. However, even with decriminalization, there are still concerns about the potential repercussions, which can be a major worry for many people.

On the other hand, there's a valid argument that arresting people for marijuana possession is costly for cities, from the initial arrest to court appearances and public defenders. This can be a significant financial burden, especially for municipalities struggling financially. Even so, some cities are hesitant to make this change, even if it could free up funds for more important community programs.

Denver, however, is a different story. Given its more open-minded and progressive attitude, I think it's perfectly fine that they've decriminalized marijuana. The extra funding can be used for things like public education, social programs for seniors, and food programs for the homeless. It's not a straightforward decision, as there are valid reasons to be cautious about marijuana being everywhere, but there's also a financial aspect to consider.

If marijuana were fully legalized, it's possible that it could become as prevalent as cigarettes, which could lead to people smoking and driving, and other issues. It's still a bit taboo in many places, so having it out in the open might be awkward for some people. While I'm not sure what I would think about that, I do know that marijuana can have different effects on people, just like alcohol. Some people can handle it better than others, and it's hard to generalize how people will react.

I think both marijuana and alcohol have their own negative effects, and it's essential to acknowledge that people respond differently to substances. Some people can be more moderate, while others might not be able to control their consumption. It's a complex issue, but I do believe that both substances have their own unique consequences.

To be honest, I'd say yes to making some changes because a lot of the practices are quite traditional. They've stuck to the same methods for a long time, and it's good to have roots in tradition. However, it's also crucial to be adaptable to change. Sometimes, I feel like the Catholic Church can be quite rigid in its expectations and doesn't accept people who don't live up to their doctrine perfectly. They also tend to be quite exclusive when it comes to people from other religions, like my parents, who are Episcopalians. They refused to let my parents get married in the Catholic Church because of my dad's background.

This isn't exactly what you'd call being tolerant of other faiths. We're taught to love others, which is a fundamental Catholic teaching, but it's hypocritical to say that and not practice it. I think the Catholic Church's doctrine often conflicts with its practices, which can be quite outdated. They stick to their traditional ways even when they're no longer relevant.

I don't think my personal views would necessarily change the situation, but personally, I think it would be a good idea for priests to be allowed to get married. However, I'm not convinced that this would deter priests who engage in pedophilic behavior. It's a different issue altogether, and people who would do such things would probably do so regardless of their marital status.

It's worth noting that people who abuse children tend to do so because of the power imbalance, not because of their marital status. Allowing priests to be married wouldn't necessarily stop these kinds of incidents from happening. It's unlikely that this would make a significant difference.

Honestly, I'm still trying to figure out where I stand on this issue, and I'm not sure if there's a right or wrong side to take. What I do know is that this is one of the most challenging topics we're dealing with right now. The line between separating church and state is a delicate one, and defining marriage is a sensitive matter that can be tricky to navigate without offending anyone. 

I'm thinking that maybe we should look at all civil unions as just that – a union between two people, without the government looking into whether it was a religious or secular ceremony. I mean, if it's just about two people coming together, then why should the government care what kind of marriage it is? It's about the bond between the individuals, not about what the government thinks of it. 

The thing is, if gay marriage is seen as just another type of civil union, then it shouldn't be a problem. It's all about two people coming together, and that's what counts. If all the states can come to a logical agreement, then it would be great if we could push for it to become federal law. But trying to ban gay marriage through a constitutional amendment is extreme – it's not the kind of thing that should be decided by amending the constitution.

I just don't think it's worth altering the constitution for a cause that's not big enough. It's a serious issue for some people, but it's not something that should warrant changing the foundation of our country. It's just not that important to define and ban gay marriage by amending the constitution. Let's keep it simple – it's about two people coming together. 

I don't know, but that's my two cents on the matter.

I grew up in a Christian household, where things got a bit hazy when it came to homosexuality. Having lots of gay friends made me think a lot about this issue, and I didn't necessarily agree with the lifestyle, but I do think it should be legalized. I think it's crazy to make it a national issue, and instead, each state should have its own say. It's like, some states are super liberal and others are more conservative, so I don't think the president should impose their views on everyone. If you live in a state that's liberal, you know how they feel about it, and if you don't like it, maybe you shouldn't move there. I think everyone should have the same opportunities, so it should be up to each state to decide. I already kind of said that, but yeah. I don't think it's right that Bush can decide for the whole country that gay marriage is against the law. He shouldn't get to dictate how each state runs itself. I mean, he's not gonna be in office forever, and if a new president comes in and thinks differently, the ban will just be lifted and then put back on again. It's simpler to just let each state decide for themselves, since they're the ones who have to live with the consequences.

Okay, let me start again. I don't agree with the idea that the school acted unreasonably. I was thinking about this, and it seems like the school's actions might have been justified. Myspace is a public platform, and anything posted there can be seen by anyone, including school officials. Even if the post wasn't made under the school's name, officials could still access it from their homes. If going through Myspace can prevent a school shooting, which is the school's responsibility, then I think it's perfectly fine.

It's like when school officials check Myspace to monitor student behavior, like whether they're drinking or smoking. They're doing it to catch students and get them in trouble, which I think is an invasion of privacy. However, if it saves lives or makes the school a safer place, I don't see it as an invasion at all. It's a bit like if they searched homes to prevent a school shooting; it's all about keeping students safe.

It's a lot easier to express myself when writing, but I guess what I'm trying to say is that posting on Myspace is a public thing, and students shouldn't be surprised if they get in trouble. I'm cautious about posting stuff online, even emails, because you never know who might see it. If you do something on Myspace, you have to be prepared for the consequences. It's not an invasion of privacy if the school officials can see it because it's a public platform.

If you do something wrong in college and grow up to be an important person, an old email can still come back to haunt you. Once something is on the internet, it's there forever, and you can't take it back. It's not an invasion of privacy if the school officials are doing it to make the school safer. I've talked to a teacher about this, and they said that they have to ensure the school is safe, like during lockdowns and drills.

In this case, the school officials were just trying to make the school a safer place, which is their responsibility. They were preventing something bad from happening, like a school shooting. So, I think they acted reasonably. That's all I have to say on the matter.

Okay, I've been thinking a lot about the war and our involvement in it. To be honest, my initial reaction was to support it after 9/11, which had a huge impact on me personally. I thought we should take action and show them the same level of devastation they brought to us. However, over time, I've come to realize that we jumped into this without a clear plan or understanding of the long-term consequences. 

Unfortunately, I think that's exactly what led to our problems. When emotions are running high, we tend to overlook the bigger picture. We went in there unprepared, not knowing what to expect, and that's exactly what backfired on us. 

To be frank, I've lost interest in the whole situation. As long as the people over there are fighting among themselves, they won't be able to focus on fighting us. It's quite evident that we're not making a difference; they're too busy infighting to care about us. Sometimes it feels like they're not even human, the way they conduct war. It's savage and brutal, and I don't think they're fighting for the betterment of their country – they just want us out.

I think we should've taken a step back and thought this through before getting involved. We were driven by a desire for revenge, and President Bush declared war on Iraq largely in response to public sentiment. At the time, I understood his position, but now I believe we could've handled it differently. We were too focused on the immediate aftermath of 9/11, and we didn't have a clear plan for what we wanted to achieve in Iraq. 

If we had unified our goals and strategies, we might have avoided some of the chaos we're seeing today. But that wasn't the case, and now I think we're stuck in a situation that's not working for us. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones who can change the people of Iraq; they're too entrenched in their ways, and we'll never be able to bring about lasting change.

As it stands, I don't think we're making enough progress to justify our continued presence in Iraq. We've achieved some things, but not enough to justify the costs. Once we leave, the situation will likely collapse, and we'll just be hurting ourselves by staying any longer. It's time to reassess our involvement and consider pulling out. That's my two cents on the matter.
