transformed_texts:
Honestly, I think the Catholic Church needs to make some changes. I'm not saying they need a complete overhaul, but they do need to adapt to modern times. They're losing followers because they're not very accepting of certain things, like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. I get that they have strong views on these issues, but they're a bit outdated. If they were to update their stance, they might not be losing so many followers. 

It's no secret that people are starting to drift away from the Catholic Church because of their views on these topics. Some individuals are even actively turning against the Church because it doesn't align with their own values. I think the Church is stuck in the past and needs to reconsider its stance on these issues. For instance, if you support abortion, you might not be comfortable with a Church that views it as morally wrong. The same goes for people who believe in gay marriage – they might not want to be part of a community that doesn't accept it.

I don't see why the Church can't have female priests or allow priests to be married. It's hard to say whether this would've made a difference in the past, but it's definitely worth considering. The Church claims that priests are married to God, dedicating their lives to their faith. However, most people with careers have both work and personal lives. It doesn't seem fair to expect priests to be any different. They should be able to have a family and devote themselves to both their faith and loved ones.

Honestly, I don't have any major issues with gay marriage. I think the idea that people are born with their sexual orientation is a strong one. In my opinion, individuals shouldn't be held accountable for who they are naturally drawn to. It's not something that's consciously chosen, and I don't think it's right to hold that against them.

I think it's unfair to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't. It's not just a matter of choice; people are who they are, and it's not something they can change. I mean, just like how I was born straight, others are born gay. They shouldn't be penalized for that.

I believe it's wrong for the government to dictate who can and can't get married. It's not a matter of law, but rather a matter of personal freedom. I don't think it's right to put people on a pedestal and say they made a wrong choice simply because of their orientation. It's not something they can help, and it's not something they should be ashamed of.

To me, the government's involvement in this issue seems out of place. It's not a matter of national security or moral values; it's about people's personal lives. They should be free to make their own choices, and the government shouldn't interfere with that. It's just who people are, and they shouldn't be punished for it.

That's my two cents on the matter.

I firmly believe that gay marriage should be legalized. The reasoning behind this is quite simple – there's no valid reason not to. Many people fear that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional families, but this is a misconception. Homosexuality and heterosexuality are two sides of the same coin, fundamentally different yet equal. It's pointless to try to draw parallels between the two, as they're distinct entities.

One of the main issues I see is that civil rights are often withheld from same-sex couples. For example, if a partner is in a same-sex relationship, they're often barred from visiting their loved one in the hospital or making important medical decisions on their behalf. This is unfair, especially considering that these partners have made a commitment to spend their lives together.

Scientific studies have shown that same-sex couples are just as successful as heterosexual couples, with similar factors contributing to relationship satisfaction. It's ridiculous to argue that two people in love, regardless of their sexual orientation, can be treated as separate entities under the law.

The crux of the issue is that gay couples aren't asking to be married in a church; they're seeking a civil union recognized by the government. If a couple is allowed a civil union, why not a marriage? It's like segregation – separate but unequal.

Many people worry about issues like adoption and how same-sex couples will integrate into their communities. Some fear that children raised by gay parents will be influenced by their parents' sexual orientation or experience social stigma. However, these concerns are often based on misconceptions and a lack of understanding.

For instance, in New York City, there are special schools for children of gay parents because they face bullying and other challenges in public schools. It's heartbreaking to see parents protesting to have their child removed from their school simply because of their parents' sexual orientation.

Ultimately, the federal government should take a strong stance on this issue and make gay marriage legal across the board. The proposed amendment is misguided and ignores the moral complexities of the issue. It's hypocritical to allow laws that enforce one group's moral standards on an entire country, especially when there are ongoing debates about issues like the Pledge of Allegiance.

Some people are opposed to gay marriage simply because they believe that being gay is a choice or a result of childhood trauma. However, this is a misconception that's been debunked by reputable institutions like the American Psychological Association. If we listened to research and facts rather than popular opinion, we might begin to see the world in a different light.

Okay, so I work at a hospital pharmacy during the summer. You know, just because a medication is banned doesn't mean it doesn't have some benefits. I'm not saying it should be available for everyone, not at all. But, for medical use, yeah, I think it's a different story. It's not beneficial just because it's illegal - that's my point.

Yeah, there are loads of controlled substances that pharmacies use all the time, like oxycodone or Vicodin. Those are used because they have benefits, right? So, if we deny the benefits of marijuana just because of a stigma around it, that doesn't make sense to me. I think we should accept its benefits and not be so quick to dismiss them.

I don't think it's as similar to booze, actually, because if you overdo it on marijuana it can have problems, but if you overdo it on booze, that's a different story altogether. It's a tricky one, but I'd say we could integrate it slowly, make it legal gradually, not all at once, or it would get abused. But first, we need to get rid of the bad rep around marijuana. People think it's terrible, but it's not as bad as heroin or cocaine. If we could change that image, people might be able to use it responsibly, especially for medical purposes.

I think the church has really adapted to the modern age. It's not as strict as it used to be. Even as I look back on my childhood, I remember always attending church on Sundays, dressed up in cute little outfits. I'd wear matching dresses, shoes, and a purse, and it was a weekly tradition. Going to a private school only made it more fun, as I'd see my friends there. But over time, I've noticed the church has relaxed its rules. They now have a shorter mass, lasting only 30 minutes, and people dress more casually, especially during the summer. You'd see families rushing in late, still in their beach clothes. Even at morning masses, people wear jeans and khakis - it's a more laid-back atmosphere.

As for other changes, this is the church I'm familiar with, but I don't know the inner workings or politics. However, it's definitely become more casual.

Regarding the recent allegations against Catholic priests regarding pedophilia, I don't believe allowing female priests or allowing priests to marry would have prevented these situations. There are married men who still have these tendencies, and it's not about whether they're allowed to get married or not. It's a personal choice to become a priest, and some people might just be drawn to that path, regardless of the rules.

Even in other faiths, like Seventh Day Adventism, there are reverends or ministers who are allowed to be married, so it's not like it's a unique issue. If someone wants to practice their faith and be married, they might consider a different religion.

When it comes to pedophilia, I think it's largely genetic. People are born with certain tendencies, and it's not something that's developed over time due to upbringing. It's possible that environment might play a small role, but I believe genetics are the main factor. Trying to change someone's sexuality through marriage wouldn't be effective, as it would likely reveal itself eventually. So, I don't think the church could have prevented these situations, even if they had made changes.

If there were cases where the church knew about the abuse and covered it up, that's a different issue altogether. However, I don't think that was the case in every situation. As for other thoughts about the Catholic Church, I don't have anything else to add.

At first, I was somewhat okay with the idea, but I think everyone was still reeling from the aftermath of the September 11th attacks. It seems to me that we invaded Iraq as a result of a series of pretexts, and the Bush administration used false connections between Saddam Hussein, Osama Bin Laden, and the 9/11 attacks to justify the war. This really didn't sit well with me, as it's now clear that Saddam Hussein didn't have WMDs, claims that were made at the time. 

I think the Bush administration has consistently lied to the American people, and to this day, they refuse to acknowledge it. Even Colin Powell, who presented the evidence at the UN, has since admitted that he wasn't convinced by it at the time. I believe this is a serious breach of trust and an impeachable offense. The administration has consistently disregarded the constitution and has been working to undermine it since 9/11, at least. It's my opinion that they came into office with the intention of going to war. 

The Bush administration's motives for invading Iraq were suspect from the start. There were allegations made by a former treasury secretary that the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein due to his father's administration, and was also looking to expand the US's energy supply, which I think is a pretty underhanded way to go about it. 

I think it's gone on long enough, but withdrawing troops now would be problematic. It's possible that the country would descend into civil war, resulting in even more casualties. The alternative plan, which involves a coalition of surrounding nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia restoring order, doesn't necessarily sit well with me either. I worry that it would lead to more issues down the line, particularly regarding Iraq's sovereignty. The interim government is already ineffective, and the Parliament is struggling to function. The Prime Minister has little control, and parties like Mugtada al-Sadr's, which holds 20 seats, are causing a lot of friction in the government. It's clear that the political process is experiencing a lot of tension due to these radical elements vying for power. 

To be honest, I'm still trying to wrap my head around the complexity of the situation. I don't have a clear solution to articulate in polite conversation.

I'm having trouble articulating my thoughts on the War in Iraq. To be honest, it's all a bit confusing because it was never officially declared a war by Congress. It seems like it was more of a reaction to the 9/11 attacks, and we're still trying to build a democracy in Iraq, which is a daunting task that will likely take a long time. I'm not really sure why we're staying there, but it's partly because of oil and also because we want to help them create a stable government.

However, it's clear that the whole situation is causing a lot of upset, and the longer we stay, the more complicated it gets. If we leave, the Iraqis might be angry with us for messing things up, but if we stay, we'll have to keep trying to impose our way of life on them, which could just make things worse. It's a tough situation, and I'm not sure what the best course of action is.

I've been thinking about this a lot, and I think we should be honest with ourselves about why we're really there. Is it because we're trying to help the Iraqis, or is it because we want to show off our military power? I'm not sure, and I think that's part of the problem. We shouldn't be calling it a war if it's not a declared one, and we shouldn't be using it as an excuse to flex our muscles.

At the same time, I feel for the families whose loved ones are over there fighting. I want to support them and want the war to be over so they can come home safely. But at the same time, I'm worried that we're just making things worse by staying there. We're disrupting their culture and way of life, and it's creating more problems than it's solving. It's like we're trying to force them to become a mini-version of the US, and that's not going to work.

I think this whole situation is going to drag on for years to come, and it's hard to know what the outcome will be. I'm just not sure what to think anymore, and it's all so complicated.

Honestly, I have doubts about making something legal or having the government declare it as such. In my opinion, it's really up to the churches to decide because the constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. This is a fundamental principle that's already been written in stone, and trying to enforce power over it would be a direct defiance of that. It seems like those pushing for it are essentially choosing one church's beliefs over another.

I think it's clear that most Catholics and Christians are against this, with some exceptions in certain areas. I don't believe it's the government's place to decide what the churches can and can't make illegal, as that's not what the constitution is about. The separation of church and state has allowed for religious tolerance in the United States, and trying to change that with an amendment would be counterintuitive and contradictory. It's also worth noting that this amendment would likely be one of the only ones used to restrict the people rather than the government.

I strongly believe that the federal government should stay out of this issue, as I don't see a valid reason for the president's push for an amendment. It seems like his actions are driven by his own Catholic beliefs, which would give preference to that particular religion over others. The churches should be the ones deciding this, not the government, and there's no concrete evidence suggesting that an amendment is necessary. In fact, it could potentially have a positive impact on society, rather than a negative one.

I think I've covered all my points on this.

You might want to read the previous post before this one.  I'm feeling a bit clearer now about the US involvement in Iraq.  I think what's making it even more complicated is the way things went down.  We started the war just a month after the terrorist attacks of September 11th, and I'm not convinced that the government was entirely honest about the reasons behind the invasion.  I genuinely think they tried to tie the two events together, even though they weren't as connected as they seemed.  The war started in 2003, and I was against it from the very beginning, especially the idea of a preemptive strike.  It's like a repeat of the Vietnam War, with the US government not learning from its past mistakes.

Think about it, a huge number of American soldiers have died in the war, and that's absolutely devastating.  The US was essentially removing the Iraqi government, but I'm not sure they were prepared for the chaos that would follow.  They wanted to establish a democratic government, just like in Vietnam, but that's not always a straightforward process.  I think the US government made it seem like it would be easy, but it's not that simple.  We're still in Iraq, and it's been years since the war started, with American troops still dying and trying to train the Iraqi military and police to take control of their country - it's a long and difficult process.

In hindsight, I think the government was not fully prepared for the aftermath of the invasion, and they might have even deceived the American people into thinking it would be a quick and successful operation.  Implementing a new form of government takes years, and it's not something that can be rushed or taken lightly, as we've seen in our own country's history.  It's not an easy thing to do, and I think the government made it seem like it was.

This was a major factor in my decision in the 2004 presidential election - I was torn between voting for George Bush, who had started the war, and the uncertainty of what would happen if we left Iraq.  It's a difficult decision, especially when we've been there for so long and taken away their government and way of life.  We can't just abandon them now, but at the same time, the number of American casualties is staggering, and it's hard to justify risking so many lives.

The reason we invaded Iraq in the first place was supposed to be to make it a democratic nation, but if that's the case, why aren't we doing the same in other countries?  I think the real reason is the oil issue - it's all about controlling resources and getting the oil.  Another factor was the supposed presence of weapons of mass destruction, but it turned out that was a false claim.  Meanwhile, countries like North Korea, which we know has those types of weapons, haven't been targeted.  It just seems like the US government is not being thorough or honest in its decision-making.

Let's hope the conflict ends soon and there's peace in Iraq, but it's hard to be optimistic about that right now.

I'm gonna be honest, I think I'm in favor of gay marriage. To be honest, I've always been this way. I believe it's a personal preference, and what's more, science now shows it's not just a social influence, but actually has a biological basis. I don't think it's fair to deny people rights based on something they can't control. It's just inhumane, in my opinion. As someone who's always been an advocate for gay marriage, I think the government should stay out of it. It's a personal matter, not a state or national issue. Look at my neighborhood, for example – there are openly gay couples living there, just like any other family. They do the same things everyone else does, like walking their dogs. It's ridiculous that Bush is trying to decide what marriage means, and I think it's kind of laughable. I've read and heard from various sources that it's actually a chemical thing in the brain, something you might be predisposed to. It's not just about how you grow up or your family dynamics. So, it's more about biology than social environment.

To be honest, the only real difference is that if a straight couple wants to get married, they can do it privately, like in Las Vegas, without anyone knowing. But if a gay couple wants to get married, it's suddenly a big public deal, splashed all over the news. I think it should be a private, personal thing, not something the government or media gets involved in.

You know, when you post something online, it's out there for everyone to see. It's a public forum, after all. As an R.A., I've already had to deal with this kind of thing. Once something's online, it can shape people's opinions about you. If you're talking about sensitive topics like blowing things up or shootings, someone's bound to notice. You can't put that kind of thing out there, because it's going to be seen by everyone. The internet is a vast and open space, and if someone's friends with you on Myspace or Facebook, they're going to get that bulletin.

It's not like the school itself got wind of the bulletin - someone had to go to the school and report it. And then the school has to act on it, because they can't just ignore it in case something actually happens. It's a matter of preventing potential harm. Of course, it's hard to know what to take seriously, because some people just mess around online. It could be like that silly experiment that went wrong in our sociology class, or it could be something really serious.

What happened in our situation is that someone overheard someone saying something at school, and then they reported it. We found out who the person was, and when we looked through their Facebook, we found some stuff that made us worried. When you post things online, you're basically giving up any expectation of privacy. If you don't want something out there, don't put it online. If you don't want someone to think something about you, you can't control that - you can't tell people what to take seriously or not.

I don't think it's a good idea for school officials to be friends with students on social media and snooping through their profiles. But if something is brought to their attention, they have to take it seriously. If it's a legitimate concern, then it's not an invasion of privacy. I mean, I wouldn't friend my residents on Facebook because I don't want to know about their personal lives, and I certainly don't want to have to deal with the consequences. That kind of relationship is just not necessary.

Honestly, I think this war has dragged on for far too long. Initially, the goal was to restore democracy in another country, which is a noble cause. However, it seems we've lost sight of that objective over time. Now, I'm not convinced we're fighting for the right reasons - it's almost like we're doing it out of habit or to prove a point as a global superpower. Looking back, I'm not sure the motives were entirely pure, especially considering George Bush's father's past conflicts with Saddam Hussein. 

I think we effectively conveyed our message in the first couple of months when we started the war, which was a powerful statement in itself. But continuing it for over a year, or even several years, just feels like an overextension. If our aim was to bring democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that's a justifiable reason for war. However, I believe our reasons have become distorted and misconceived over time. It seems like we're still fighting for the sake of fighting, and not wanting to leave without a clear victory.

Honestly, I think it's time to bring this to an end. The government of the country we're fighting in should be able to fend for themselves now. We've been draining our own economy, spending billions of dollars on this conflict when we have our own domestic issues like poverty and infrastructure that need attention. It's a financial burden we can no longer afford, especially when that money could be better spent on internal improvements like public roads, education, and healthcare.

We've got our own problems to address at home, including poverty, healthcare, and education. It's disheartening to see money being spent on casualties in a foreign war that we've lost sight of our purpose for. I think it's time to reassess our priorities and end this war once and for all.

To clarify, something was able to be prevented because someone found your profile online, right? It's because if you post stuff on the internet, it's pretty much available for everyone to see. On sites like Myspace, you have to let someone be your friend to see your profile, but you're basically giving them permission to see it once you add them. So, anytime you put info online, you should understand that lots of people are going to see it.

It's a tough spot because, on the one hand, you can't have one person constantly monitoring everyone's profiles to prevent something bad from happening. On the other hand, it becomes unfair to single out certain people and make it their job to check up on everyone. It really depends on the situation - were they just randomly looking around or were they actively searching for something specific?

Personality, I have a Facebook, and it bothers me that there are people out there who can see my stuff. I saw this one show that showed how easily someone could get info on a girl's profile, and it freaked me out. They got her screen name and started chatting with her in under a minute. I know some people in my classes who I don't know, but they know my screen name and where I am during the day. It's hard to know who can see what online, so I try to limit what I post, but I don't want to limit it too much since the whole point is to stay in touch with friends.

It's a tricky issue because you have to accept people as friends to see your profile, but you never know who can actually see what. I heard that some schools banned students from having Myspace profiles, and that seems a bit strange - I'm not sure how they had the right to do that.

I'm starting to think about this more and it's making me realize how complex the situation with the Iraq War is. Honestly, I feel a bit hypocritical talking about it now, but I've come to the conclusion that it was a bad idea from the beginning. Looking back, it's clear that the general consensus was against it, except within the administration, where they didn't want to admit their mistake. Recent polls have shown that around 75-80% of the world's population thinks it was a bad idea, including 80% of Iraqis and 70% of US troops currently stationed there. It's astonishing to see such a high percentage of people against the war, both in the US and globally.

The situation has been a disaster from the start, and it's difficult to see a way out. The cultural differences between the US and the Middle East are vast, and administrations have consistently failed to understand this. The idea that democracy can be imposed on a region where it's not wanted is unrealistic. While Saddam was a bad leader, you have to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country that's likely to become a disaster. The situation has been like quicksand since we entered, and I don't see any reason for us to stay.

I'm sure the administration has some hopeful ideas about why we should stay, but I've yet to hear a valid reason. If they want to withdraw gradually over a year or more, I wouldn't have a problem with that, but I don't see a reason why we can't leave now. It's worth noting that 80% of Iraqis think we should be gone within a year, and at least a quarter of them want us to leave immediately. It's ironic that we're trying to 'save' them, yet they're telling us to leave. If we ask them if we should stay, and they say no, it's not on us if things go wrong. If we do decide to help out after that, at least we'll be seen as the 'good guys,' even if it's a stretch.

Okay, let's talk about this. I really believe that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States. It's not just limited to women, either - it's also a problem in certain fields. I think that women, in general, face more challenges due to the "glass ceiling" that exists, even when it seems like there should be equality. This is because of the way society has been raised for so long, where men are often expected to be in charge.

In the workplace, women may have all the qualifications for a position, but they might be overlooked because it's not common for women to reach senior positions. This isn't just a women's issue, though - men can face similar challenges too. For example, in fields like fashion or parenting, it's unusual for men to be the primary caregiver, and they can be judged for it. People might think, "You're a man, you should be working and providing for the family, not staying at home with the kids."

It's also an issue in the fashion industry, where people might not take men seriously if they're straight and interested in fashion. This is because men who enjoy fashion are often stereotyped as having a different lifestyle, and people might wonder if they really understand what fashion is all about.

Changing this mindset is hard because society has a set way of thinking. We've made progress since the 1800s, but it's a slow process. However, as more women rise to leadership positions and become accepted in the business world, things are starting to shift. Men are also becoming more accepted as stay-at-home dads, and people are beginning to realize that it's okay for men to take on this role.

I think we need to promote the good qualities of people who are often stereotyped against, but in a way that's not pushy. If we force it, people will resist. We're at a good point right now where things are starting to become more accepted, but we need to keep this momentum going. It's not just a matter of gender, either - people from different backgrounds or with different job skills can face prejudice too.

For example, someone from a rural area might be judged for their grammar, even if they're highly intelligent and capable. Other men might look down on them, saying, "How can I trust what you're saying if you can't even put together a simple sentence?" It's not just about gender, but also about where you're from and how you speak.

So, yeah, that's my take on it. I don't think we're doing enough, but I'm not sure what more we can do at this point. We just need to keep moving forward, one step at a time.

So, it seems that in some areas, marijuana isn't fully legalized, but rather decriminalized, which means it's more like a traffic ticket than a serious crime. This can have implications for things like job interviews, but the effects of a marijuana charge don't necessarily disappear even if it's decriminalized. For instance, when it comes to marijuana, one of the main concerns is the long-term consequences, which can be a real worry for many people.

On the other hand, there's an argument that arresting and prosecuting people for marijuana possession is a costly endeavor. It involves booking, housing, public defenders, judges, and the state attorney's office, all of which add up. In financially struggling municipalities, some cities might be hesitant to make this change, even if it would free up funds for other important community projects.

However, in places like Denver, where people tend to be more open-minded, decriminalizing marijuana can be a great move, allowing the city to redirect funds towards public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. It's a complex issue with both financial and social implications.

One thing to consider is that if marijuana were fully legalized, it could lead to its increased presence in public spaces, which might be uncomfortable for some people. Additionally, it's worth noting that while marijuana's effects on motor skills are often compared to those of alcohol, it can also have a significant impact on people's lifestyles. Ultimately, people react differently to substances, and it's hard to generalize how they'll be affected.

I'd definitely agree with you because many Catholic practices are steeped in tradition. For instance, they've been following the same customs for a long time. While it's great to be rooted in tradition, it's also essential to be open to change. A lot of Catholics attend church every week and have strict rules about how things should be done. Unfortunately, I think the Catholic Church can come across as judgmental towards people who don't adhere strictly to their doctrine. Moreover, they don't always welcome people from other faiths or those who aren't perfect Catholics. This was evident in my family's situation – my parents, one a Catholic and the other an Episcopalian, couldn't get married in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion. It's hard to see this as tolerance, especially when you consider that the Catholic Church teaches people to love others. It's hypocritical to say you love others but not accept them. I believe the Catholic Church's teachings often contradict their practices, which can be outdated. They stick to these outdated practices, even though they don't align with their teachings.

I'm not sure if allowing priests to marry would necessarily make them less likely to engage in pedophilic behavior. It's a complex issue, and I don't think it would be a simple solution. People who abuse children are likely to do so regardless of their marital status. Children are a different situation than spouses, and it's unlikely that marriage would prevent such behavior.

In my opinion, allowing priests to be married wouldn't necessarily prevent these types of incidents from occurring. I think it's possible that these actions would still happen even if priests were allowed to marry. It's a complex issue that requires a deeper look.

Honestly, I'm still unsure about this issue, and I'm struggling to form an opinion. It's tough to say who's right or wrong in this situation. I do think, though, that this is one of the most challenging topics we're facing today. The line between church and state is already blurry, and defining marriage is a delicate matter that can easily offend someone. To be honest, I'm not convinced that marriage should be viewed as solely a government-defined institution. Considering it's also a deeply personal and sacred commitment, it's hard to see it as just a civil union. I mean, if two people get married, it's about their union, not about the specific type of marriage they've chosen or the church they attend. So, I think it should be viewed as a civil union, rather than a marriage with government-recognized status. 

I also think it's worth noting that the fact that gay marriage is being debated is a bit puzzling. To me, two people in a relationship are entitled to a civil union, regardless of their sexual orientation. If all states can come to a mutually beneficial agreement, then it should be pushed forward as a federal law. However, making a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage seems unnecessary and extreme. It's not a widespread issue that warrants a constitutional amendment. It's just not something significant enough to alter the constitution.

Honestly, I don't think so.

Honestly, I come from a Christian background, and to be honest, this has left me with some mixed feelings about homosexuality. On one hand, I have lots of gay friends, so it's not something I can just dismiss. While I don't personally agree with the way of life, I do think it should be a matter of personal freedom. I believe it's not the government's place to make this decision for everyone, but rather each state should be able to decide for itself.

It makes sense that in democratic states, there's a higher likelihood of support for gay marriage, and if you live in one of those states, it's hard to argue with the majority opinion. I think it's only fair that individuals are given the same rights as everyone else, so I think it should be up to each state to decide whether or not to legalize gay marriage.

As for President Bush's stance on the issue, I don't think he should have the power to dictate the entire country's views on this. Just because he's in office doesn't mean he gets to decide how every state runs itself. Plus, his views will likely change soon anyway - he's only in office for a couple more years, and if a democratic president comes in and lifts the ban on gay marriage, the decision will probably just flip-flop. It's really up to each state to decide what's best for its own citizens, as they're the ones who will have to live with the consequences of that decision.

So I'm trying to figure this out, but let's be real, Myspace is a public platform. If you post something on it, you have to accept that people will see it. That includes school officials, whether they're doing it under the school's name or not. They can access it from home, and in my opinion, if it means preventing a school shooting and saving lives, that's perfectly fine. I think it's the school's responsibility to ensure the safety of its students.

If school officials go on the internet to see if students are doing things they shouldn't be, like drinking or smoking, it feels like an invasion of privacy. But if it leads to making the school a better and safer place, I don't think that's an invasion at all. It's like when they do random checks to catch students doing something they shouldn't be doing, but that's a different story.

I feel like posting something on Myspace and not expecting to get in trouble is unrealistic. Everything can be found online, and it can come back to haunt you. If you post something as a college student, it can follow you for the rest of your life. Once it's on the internet, it's there forever.

I'm not saying I think it's okay for school officials to go on the internet just to catch students, but if they have a reason to do so, like to make the school a safer place, then that's a different story. It's like when parents drop off their kids at school, they expect it to be a safe place. I've talked to a teacher about this, and they said that's exactly why they monitor online activity.

They had to do lockdown drills and stuff because of the Columbine incident. They were just trying to prevent anything bad from happening. In this case, school officials were doing the same thing - making the school a safer place by preventing a potential school shooting. That's all I'm saying.

Okay, I've been thinking a lot about the whole thing. To be honest, I was initially all for it after 9/11 because it was a personal issue for me. I had strong feelings and wanted to do something, but now I'm not so sure. I think we rushed into it without thinking about the long-term consequences. We just kind of went in without a clear plan and, in my opinion, it backfired. Honestly, I was all for it at first, but my feelings have changed. I don't think we accomplished anything by being there. I think the people in that region are too busy fighting each other to focus on fighting us too. It's hard for me to care about what's going on over there because of how they seem to be handling things. It's almost like they're not even human in the way they go to war. They just can't seem to work together, and that's why I don't think we should be there.

I think we went in unprepared and didn't know what we were getting ourselves into. War is a completely different experience for them than for us. They're not looking to improve their country; they're just trying to get rid of us. I think we should just leave and be done with it. We were initially driven by emotions and a desire for revenge, but I don't think we were thinking rationally about the potential consequences. We were more hyped up than focused on creating a solution.

I understand why President Bush made the decision to declare war on Iraq at the time, but I'm not sure we had a choice. However, I do think we could have come up with a better plan and been more united in our goals. We didn't seem to know what we were doing or what we wanted to achieve, and that made things worse. I don't think we're the right people to change them; they've been that way for a long time, and it's not going to change overnight. I don't think we're making enough progress, and it's pointless to stay there any longer. Once we leave, I think it will just collapse, and we can't stay forever. I think we're just hurting ourselves by staying. That's my honest opinion.

transformed_texts:
Honestly, I think the Catholic Church needs to make some changes. I'm not saying they need a complete overhaul, but they do need to adapt to modern times. They're losing followers because they're not very accepting of certain things, like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. I get that they have strong views on these issues, but they're a bit outdated. If they were to update their stance, they might not be losing so many followers. 

It's no secret that people are starting to drift away from the Catholic Church because of their views on these topics. Some individuals are even actively turning against the Church because it doesn't align with their own values. I think the Church is stuck in the past and needs to reconsider its stance on these issues. For instance, if you support abortion, you might not be comfortable with a Church that views it as morally wrong. The same goes for people who believe in gay marriage – they might not want to be part of a community that doesn't accept it.

I don't see why the Church can't have female priests or allow priests to be married. It's hard to say whether this would've made a difference in the past, but it's definitely worth considering. The Church claims that priests are married to God, dedicating their lives to their faith. However, most people with careers have both work and personal lives. It doesn't seem fair to expect priests to be any different. They should be able to have a family and devote themselves to both their faith and loved ones.

Honestly, I don't have any major issues with gay marriage. I think the idea that people are born with their sexual orientation is a strong one. In my opinion, individuals shouldn't be held accountable for who they are naturally drawn to. It's not something that's consciously chosen, and I don't think it's right to hold that against them.

I think it's unfair to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't. It's not just a matter of choice; people are who they are, and it's not something they can change. I mean, just like how I was born straight, others are born gay. They shouldn't be penalized for that.

I believe it's wrong for the government to dictate who can and can't get married. It's not a matter of law, but rather a matter of personal freedom. I don't think it's right to put people on a pedestal and say they made a wrong choice simply because of their orientation. It's not something they can help, and it's not something they should be ashamed of.

To me, the government's involvement in this issue seems out of place. It's not a matter of national security or moral values; it's about people's personal lives. They should be free to make their own choices, and the government shouldn't interfere with that. It's just who people are, and they shouldn't be punished for it.

That's my two cents on the matter.

I firmly believe that gay marriage should be legalized. The reasoning behind this is quite simple – there's no valid reason not to. Many people fear that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional families, but this is a misconception. Homosexuality and heterosexuality are two sides of the same coin, fundamentally different yet equal. It's pointless to try to draw parallels between the two, as they're distinct entities.

One of the main issues I see is that civil rights are often withheld from same-sex couples. For example, if a partner is in a same-sex relationship, they're often barred from visiting their loved one in the hospital or making important medical decisions on their behalf. This is unfair, especially considering that these partners have made a commitment to spend their lives together.

Scientific studies have shown that same-sex couples are just as successful as heterosexual couples, with similar factors contributing to relationship satisfaction. It's ridiculous to argue that two people in love, regardless of their sexual orientation, can be treated as separate entities under the law.

The crux of the issue is that gay couples aren't asking to be married in a church; they're seeking a civil union recognized by the government. If a couple is allowed a civil union, why not a marriage? It's like segregation – separate but unequal.

Many people worry about issues like adoption and how same-sex couples will integrate into their communities. Some fear that children raised by gay parents will be influenced by their parents' sexual orientation or experience social stigma. However, these concerns are often based on misconceptions and a lack of understanding.

For instance, in New York City, there are special schools for children of gay parents because they face bullying and other challenges in public schools. It's heartbreaking to see parents protesting to have their child removed from their school simply because of their parents' sexual orientation.

Ultimately, the federal government should take a strong stance on this issue and make gay marriage legal across the board. The proposed amendment is misguided and ignores the moral complexities of the issue. It's hypocritical to allow laws that enforce one group's moral standards on an entire country, especially when there are ongoing debates about issues like the Pledge of Allegiance.

Some people are opposed to gay marriage simply because they believe that being gay is a choice or a result of childhood trauma. However, this is a misconception that's been debunked by reputable institutions like the American Psychological Association. If we listened to research and facts rather than popular opinion, we might begin to see the world in a different light.

Okay, so I work at a hospital pharmacy during the summer. You know, just because a medication is banned doesn't mean it doesn't have some benefits. I'm not saying it should be available for everyone, not at all. But, for medical use, yeah, I think it's a different story. It's not beneficial just because it's illegal - that's my point.

Yeah, there are loads of controlled substances that pharmacies use all the time, like oxycodone or Vicodin. Those are used because they have benefits, right? So, if we deny the benefits of marijuana just because of a stigma around it, that doesn't make sense to me. I think we should accept its benefits and not be so quick to dismiss them.

I don't think it's as similar to booze, actually, because if you overdo it on marijuana it can have problems, but if you overdo it on booze, that's a different story altogether. It's a tricky one, but I'd say we could integrate it slowly, make it legal gradually, not all at once, or it would get abused. But first, we need to get rid of the bad rep around marijuana. People think it's terrible, but it's not as bad as heroin or cocaine. If we could change that image, people might be able to use it responsibly, especially for medical purposes.

I think the church has really adapted to the modern age. It's not as strict as it used to be. Even as I look back on my childhood, I remember always attending church on Sundays, dressed up in cute little outfits. I'd wear matching dresses, shoes, and a purse, and it was a weekly tradition. Going to a private school only made it more fun, as I'd see my friends there. But over time, I've noticed the church has relaxed its rules. They now have a shorter mass, lasting only 30 minutes, and people dress more casually, especially during the summer. You'd see families rushing in late, still in their beach clothes. Even at morning masses, people wear jeans and khakis - it's a more laid-back atmosphere.

As for other changes, this is the church I'm familiar with, but I don't know the inner workings or politics. However, it's definitely become more casual.

Regarding the recent allegations against Catholic priests regarding pedophilia, I don't believe allowing female priests or allowing priests to marry would have prevented these situations. There are married men who still have these tendencies, and it's not about whether they're allowed to get married or not. It's a personal choice to become a priest, and some people might just be drawn to that path, regardless of the rules.

Even in other faiths, like Seventh Day Adventism, there are reverends or ministers who are allowed to be married, so it's not like it's a unique issue. If someone wants to practice their faith and be married, they might consider a different religion.

When it comes to pedophilia, I think it's largely genetic. People are born with certain tendencies, and it's not something that's developed over time due to upbringing. It's possible that environment might play a small role, but I believe genetics are the main factor. Trying to change someone's sexuality through marriage wouldn't be effective, as it would likely reveal itself eventually. So, I don't think the church could have prevented these situations, even if they had made changes.

If there were cases where the church knew about the abuse and covered it up, that's a different issue altogether. However, I don't think that was the case in every situation. As for other thoughts about the Catholic Church, I don't have anything else to add.

At first, I was somewhat okay with the idea, but I think everyone was still reeling from the aftermath of the September 11th attacks. It seems to me that we invaded Iraq as a result of a series of pretexts, and the Bush administration used false connections between Saddam Hussein, Osama Bin Laden, and the 9/11 attacks to justify the war. This really didn't sit well with me, as it's now clear that Saddam Hussein didn't have WMDs, claims that were made at the time. 

I think the Bush administration has consistently lied to the American people, and to this day, they refuse to acknowledge it. Even Colin Powell, who presented the evidence at the UN, has since admitted that he wasn't convinced by it at the time. I believe this is a serious breach of trust and an impeachable offense. The administration has consistently disregarded the constitution and has been working to undermine it since 9/11, at least. It's my opinion that they came into office with the intention of going to war. 

The Bush administration's motives for invading Iraq were suspect from the start. There were allegations made by a former treasury secretary that the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein due to his father's administration, and was also looking to expand the US's energy supply, which I think is a pretty underhanded way to go about it. 

I think it's gone on long enough, but withdrawing troops now would be problematic. It's possible that the country would descend into civil war, resulting in even more casualties. The alternative plan, which involves a coalition of surrounding nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia restoring order, doesn't necessarily sit well with me either. I worry that it would lead to more issues down the line, particularly regarding Iraq's sovereignty. The interim government is already ineffective, and the Parliament is struggling to function. The Prime Minister has little control, and parties like Mugtada al-Sadr's, which holds 20 seats, are causing a lot of friction in the government. It's clear that the political process is experiencing a lot of tension due to these radical elements vying for power. 

To be honest, I'm still trying to wrap my head around the complexity of the situation. I don't have a clear solution to articulate in polite conversation.

I'm having trouble articulating my thoughts on the War in Iraq. To be honest, it's all a bit confusing because it was never officially declared a war by Congress. It seems like it was more of a reaction to the 9/11 attacks, and we're still trying to build a democracy in Iraq, which is a daunting task that will likely take a long time. I'm not really sure why we're staying there, but it's partly because of oil and also because we want to help them create a stable government.

However, it's clear that the whole situation is causing a lot of upset, and the longer we stay, the more complicated it gets. If we leave, the Iraqis might be angry with us for messing things up, but if we stay, we'll have to keep trying to impose our way of life on them, which could just make things worse. It's a tough situation, and I'm not sure what the best course of action is.

I've been thinking about this a lot, and I think we should be honest with ourselves about why we're really there. Is it because we're trying to help the Iraqis, or is it because we want to show off our military power? I'm not sure, and I think that's part of the problem. We shouldn't be calling it a war if it's not a declared one, and we shouldn't be using it as an excuse to flex our muscles.

At the same time, I feel for the families whose loved ones are over there fighting. I want to support them and want the war to be over so they can come home safely. But at the same time, I'm worried that we're just making things worse by staying there. We're disrupting their culture and way of life, and it's creating more problems than it's solving. It's like we're trying to force them to become a mini-version of the US, and that's not going to work.

I think this whole situation is going to drag on for years to come, and it's hard to know what the outcome will be. I'm just not sure what to think anymore, and it's all so complicated.

Honestly, I have doubts about making something legal or having the government declare it as such. In my opinion, it's really up to the churches to decide because the constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. This is a fundamental principle that's already been written in stone, and trying to enforce power over it would be a direct defiance of that. It seems like those pushing for it are essentially choosing one church's beliefs over another.

I think it's clear that most Catholics and Christians are against this, with some exceptions in certain areas. I don't believe it's the government's place to decide what the churches can and can't make illegal, as that's not what the constitution is about. The separation of church and state has allowed for religious tolerance in the United States, and trying to change that with an amendment would be counterintuitive and contradictory. It's also worth noting that this amendment would likely be one of the only ones used to restrict the people rather than the government.

I strongly believe that the federal government should stay out of this issue, as I don't see a valid reason for the president's push for an amendment. It seems like his actions are driven by his own Catholic beliefs, which would give preference to that particular religion over others. The churches should be the ones deciding this, not the government, and there's no concrete evidence suggesting that an amendment is necessary. In fact, it could potentially have a positive impact on society, rather than a negative one.

I think I've covered all my points on this.

You might want to read the previous post before this one.  I'm feeling a bit clearer now about the US involvement in Iraq.  I think what's making it even more complicated is the way things went down.  We started the war just a month after the terrorist attacks of September 11th, and I'm not convinced that the government was entirely honest about the reasons behind the invasion.  I genuinely think they tried to tie the two events together, even though they weren't as connected as they seemed.  The war started in 2003, and I was against it from the very beginning, especially the idea of a preemptive strike.  It's like a repeat of the Vietnam War, with the US government not learning from its past mistakes.

Think about it, a huge number of American soldiers have died in the war, and that's absolutely devastating.  The US was essentially removing the Iraqi government, but I'm not sure they were prepared for the chaos that would follow.  They wanted to establish a democratic government, just like in Vietnam, but that's not always a straightforward process.  I think the US government made it seem like it would be easy, but it's not that simple.  We're still in Iraq, and it's been years since the war started, with American troops still dying and trying to train the Iraqi military and police to take control of their country - it's a long and difficult process.

In hindsight, I think the government was not fully prepared for the aftermath of the invasion, and they might have even deceived the American people into thinking it would be a quick and successful operation.  Implementing a new form of government takes years, and it's not something that can be rushed or taken lightly, as we've seen in our own country's history.  It's not an easy thing to do, and I think the government made it seem like it was.

This was a major factor in my decision in the 2004 presidential election - I was torn between voting for George Bush, who had started the war, and the uncertainty of what would happen if we left Iraq.  It's a difficult decision, especially when we've been there for so long and taken away their government and way of life.  We can't just abandon them now, but at the same time, the number of American casualties is staggering, and it's hard to justify risking so many lives.

The reason we invaded Iraq in the first place was supposed to be to make it a democratic nation, but if that's the case, why aren't we doing the same in other countries?  I think the real reason is the oil issue - it's all about controlling resources and getting the oil.  Another factor was the supposed presence of weapons of mass destruction, but it turned out that was a false claim.  Meanwhile, countries like North Korea, which we know has those types of weapons, haven't been targeted.  It just seems like the US government is not being thorough or honest in its decision-making.

Let's hope the conflict ends soon and there's peace in Iraq, but it's hard to be optimistic about that right now.

I'm gonna be honest, I think I'm in favor of gay marriage. To be honest, I've always been this way. I believe it's a personal preference, and what's more, science now shows it's not just a social influence, but actually has a biological basis. I don't think it's fair to deny people rights based on something they can't control. It's just inhumane, in my opinion. As someone who's always been an advocate for gay marriage, I think the government should stay out of it. It's a personal matter, not a state or national issue. Look at my neighborhood, for example – there are openly gay couples living there, just like any other family. They do the same things everyone else does, like walking their dogs. It's ridiculous that Bush is trying to decide what marriage means, and I think it's kind of laughable. I've read and heard from various sources that it's actually a chemical thing in the brain, something you might be predisposed to. It's not just about how you grow up or your family dynamics. So, it's more about biology than social environment.

To be honest, the only real difference is that if a straight couple wants to get married, they can do it privately, like in Las Vegas, without anyone knowing. But if a gay couple wants to get married, it's suddenly a big public deal, splashed all over the news. I think it should be a private, personal thing, not something the government or media gets involved in.

You know, when you post something online, it's out there for everyone to see. It's a public forum, after all. As an R.A., I've already had to deal with this kind of thing. Once something's online, it can shape people's opinions about you. If you're talking about sensitive topics like blowing things up or shootings, someone's bound to notice. You can't put that kind of thing out there, because it's going to be seen by everyone. The internet is a vast and open space, and if someone's friends with you on Myspace or Facebook, they're going to get that bulletin.

It's not like the school itself got wind of the bulletin - someone had to go to the school and report it. And then the school has to act on it, because they can't just ignore it in case something actually happens. It's a matter of preventing potential harm. Of course, it's hard to know what to take seriously, because some people just mess around online. It could be like that silly experiment that went wrong in our sociology class, or it could be something really serious.

What happened in our situation is that someone overheard someone saying something at school, and then they reported it. We found out who the person was, and when we looked through their Facebook, we found some stuff that made us worried. When you post things online, you're basically giving up any expectation of privacy. If you don't want something out there, don't put it online. If you don't want someone to think something about you, you can't control that - you can't tell people what to take seriously or not.

I don't think it's a good idea for school officials to be friends with students on social media and snooping through their profiles. But if something is brought to their attention, they have to take it seriously. If it's a legitimate concern, then it's not an invasion of privacy. I mean, I wouldn't friend my residents on Facebook because I don't want to know about their personal lives, and I certainly don't want to have to deal with the consequences. That kind of relationship is just not necessary.

Honestly, I think this war has dragged on for far too long. Initially, the goal was to restore democracy in another country, which is a noble cause. However, it seems we've lost sight of that objective over time. Now, I'm not convinced we're fighting for the right reasons - it's almost like we're doing it out of habit or to prove a point as a global superpower. Looking back, I'm not sure the motives were entirely pure, especially considering George Bush's father's past conflicts with Saddam Hussein. 

I think we effectively conveyed our message in the first couple of months when we started the war, which was a powerful statement in itself. But continuing it for over a year, or even several years, just feels like an overextension. If our aim was to bring democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that's a justifiable reason for war. However, I believe our reasons have become distorted and misconceived over time. It seems like we're still fighting for the sake of fighting, and not wanting to leave without a clear victory.

Honestly, I think it's time to bring this to an end. The government of the country we're fighting in should be able to fend for themselves now. We've been draining our own economy, spending billions of dollars on this conflict when we have our own domestic issues like poverty and infrastructure that need attention. It's a financial burden we can no longer afford, especially when that money could be better spent on internal improvements like public roads, education, and healthcare.

We've got our own problems to address at home, including poverty, healthcare, and education. It's disheartening to see money being spent on casualties in a foreign war that we've lost sight of our purpose for. I think it's time to reassess our priorities and end this war once and for all.

To clarify, something was able to be prevented because someone found your profile online, right? It's because if you post stuff on the internet, it's pretty much available for everyone to see. On sites like Myspace, you have to let someone be your friend to see your profile, but you're basically giving them permission to see it once you add them. So, anytime you put info online, you should understand that lots of people are going to see it.

It's a tough spot because, on the one hand, you can't have one person constantly monitoring everyone's profiles to prevent something bad from happening. On the other hand, it becomes unfair to single out certain people and make it their job to check up on everyone. It really depends on the situation - were they just randomly looking around or were they actively searching for something specific?

Personality, I have a Facebook, and it bothers me that there are people out there who can see my stuff. I saw this one show that showed how easily someone could get info on a girl's profile, and it freaked me out. They got her screen name and started chatting with her in under a minute. I know some people in my classes who I don't know, but they know my screen name and where I am during the day. It's hard to know who can see what online, so I try to limit what I post, but I don't want to limit it too much since the whole point is to stay in touch with friends.

It's a tricky issue because you have to accept people as friends to see your profile, but you never know who can actually see what. I heard that some schools banned students from having Myspace profiles, and that seems a bit strange - I'm not sure how they had the right to do that.

I'm starting to think about this more and it's making me realize how complex the situation with the Iraq War is. Honestly, I feel a bit hypocritical talking about it now, but I've come to the conclusion that it was a bad idea from the beginning. Looking back, it's clear that the general consensus was against it, except within the administration, where they didn't want to admit their mistake. Recent polls have shown that around 75-80% of the world's population thinks it was a bad idea, including 80% of Iraqis and 70% of US troops currently stationed there. It's astonishing to see such a high percentage of people against the war, both in the US and globally.

The situation has been a disaster from the start, and it's difficult to see a way out. The cultural differences between the US and the Middle East are vast, and administrations have consistently failed to understand this. The idea that democracy can be imposed on a region where it's not wanted is unrealistic. While Saddam was a bad leader, you have to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country that's likely to become a disaster. The situation has been like quicksand since we entered, and I don't see any reason for us to stay.

I'm sure the administration has some hopeful ideas about why we should stay, but I've yet to hear a valid reason. If they want to withdraw gradually over a year or more, I wouldn't have a problem with that, but I don't see a reason why we can't leave now. It's worth noting that 80% of Iraqis think we should be gone within a year, and at least a quarter of them want us to leave immediately. It's ironic that we're trying to 'save' them, yet they're telling us to leave. If we ask them if we should stay, and they say no, it's not on us if things go wrong. If we do decide to help out after that, at least we'll be seen as the 'good guys,' even if it's a stretch.

Okay, let's talk about this. I really believe that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States. It's not just limited to women, either - it's also a problem in certain fields. I think that women, in general, face more challenges due to the "glass ceiling" that exists, even when it seems like there should be equality. This is because of the way society has been raised for so long, where men are often expected to be in charge.

In the workplace, women may have all the qualifications for a position, but they might be overlooked because it's not common for women to reach senior positions. This isn't just a women's issue, though - men can face similar challenges too. For example, in fields like fashion or parenting, it's unusual for men to be the primary caregiver, and they can be judged for it. People might think, "You're a man, you should be working and providing for the family, not staying at home with the kids."

It's also an issue in the fashion industry, where people might not take men seriously if they're straight and interested in fashion. This is because men who enjoy fashion are often stereotyped as having a different lifestyle, and people might wonder if they really understand what fashion is all about.

Changing this mindset is hard because society has a set way of thinking. We've made progress since the 1800s, but it's a slow process. However, as more women rise to leadership positions and become accepted in the business world, things are starting to shift. Men are also becoming more accepted as stay-at-home dads, and people are beginning to realize that it's okay for men to take on this role.

I think we need to promote the good qualities of people who are often stereotyped against, but in a way that's not pushy. If we force it, people will resist. We're at a good point right now where things are starting to become more accepted, but we need to keep this momentum going. It's not just a matter of gender, either - people from different backgrounds or with different job skills can face prejudice too.

For example, someone from a rural area might be judged for their grammar, even if they're highly intelligent and capable. Other men might look down on them, saying, "How can I trust what you're saying if you can't even put together a simple sentence?" It's not just about gender, but also about where you're from and how you speak.

So, yeah, that's my take on it. I don't think we're doing enough, but I'm not sure what more we can do at this point. We just need to keep moving forward, one step at a time.

So, it seems that in some areas, marijuana isn't fully legalized, but rather decriminalized, which means it's more like a traffic ticket than a serious crime. This can have implications for things like job interviews, but the effects of a marijuana charge don't necessarily disappear even if it's decriminalized. For instance, when it comes to marijuana, one of the main concerns is the long-term consequences, which can be a real worry for many people.

On the other hand, there's an argument that arresting and prosecuting people for marijuana possession is a costly endeavor. It involves booking, housing, public defenders, judges, and the state attorney's office, all of which add up. In financially struggling municipalities, some cities might be hesitant to make this change, even if it would free up funds for other important community projects.

However, in places like Denver, where people tend to be more open-minded, decriminalizing marijuana can be a great move, allowing the city to redirect funds towards public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. It's a complex issue with both financial and social implications.

One thing to consider is that if marijuana were fully legalized, it could lead to its increased presence in public spaces, which might be uncomfortable for some people. Additionally, it's worth noting that while marijuana's effects on motor skills are often compared to those of alcohol, it can also have a significant impact on people's lifestyles. Ultimately, people react differently to substances, and it's hard to generalize how they'll be affected.

I'd definitely agree with you because many Catholic practices are steeped in tradition. For instance, they've been following the same customs for a long time. While it's great to be rooted in tradition, it's also essential to be open to change. A lot of Catholics attend church every week and have strict rules about how things should be done. Unfortunately, I think the Catholic Church can come across as judgmental towards people who don't adhere strictly to their doctrine. Moreover, they don't always welcome people from other faiths or those who aren't perfect Catholics. This was evident in my family's situation – my parents, one a Catholic and the other an Episcopalian, couldn't get married in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion. It's hard to see this as tolerance, especially when you consider that the Catholic Church teaches people to love others. It's hypocritical to say you love others but not accept them. I believe the Catholic Church's teachings often contradict their practices, which can be outdated. They stick to these outdated practices, even though they don't align with their teachings.

I'm not sure if allowing priests to marry would necessarily make them less likely to engage in pedophilic behavior. It's a complex issue, and I don't think it would be a simple solution. People who abuse children are likely to do so regardless of their marital status. Children are a different situation than spouses, and it's unlikely that marriage would prevent such behavior.

In my opinion, allowing priests to be married wouldn't necessarily prevent these types of incidents from occurring. I think it's possible that these actions would still happen even if priests were allowed to marry. It's a complex issue that requires a deeper look.

Honestly, I'm still unsure about this issue, and I'm struggling to form an opinion. It's tough to say who's right or wrong in this situation. I do think, though, that this is one of the most challenging topics we're facing today. The line between church and state is already blurry, and defining marriage is a delicate matter that can easily offend someone. To be honest, I'm not convinced that marriage should be viewed as solely a government-defined institution. Considering it's also a deeply personal and sacred commitment, it's hard to see it as just a civil union. I mean, if two people get married, it's about their union, not about the specific type of marriage they've chosen or the church they attend. So, I think it should be viewed as a civil union, rather than a marriage with government-recognized status. 

I also think it's worth noting that the fact that gay marriage is being debated is a bit puzzling. To me, two people in a relationship are entitled to a civil union, regardless of their sexual orientation. If all states can come to a mutually beneficial agreement, then it should be pushed forward as a federal law. However, making a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage seems unnecessary and extreme. It's not a widespread issue that warrants a constitutional amendment. It's just not something significant enough to alter the constitution.

Honestly, I don't think so.

Honestly, I come from a Christian background, and to be honest, this has left me with some mixed feelings about homosexuality. On one hand, I have lots of gay friends, so it's not something I can just dismiss. While I don't personally agree with the way of life, I do think it should be a matter of personal freedom. I believe it's not the government's place to make this decision for everyone, but rather each state should be able to decide for itself.

It makes sense that in democratic states, there's a higher likelihood of support for gay marriage, and if you live in one of those states, it's hard to argue with the majority opinion. I think it's only fair that individuals are given the same rights as everyone else, so I think it should be up to each state to decide whether or not to legalize gay marriage.

As for President Bush's stance on the issue, I don't think he should have the power to dictate the entire country's views on this. Just because he's in office doesn't mean he gets to decide how every state runs itself. Plus, his views will likely change soon anyway - he's only in office for a couple more years, and if a democratic president comes in and lifts the ban on gay marriage, the decision will probably just flip-flop. It's really up to each state to decide what's best for its own citizens, as they're the ones who will have to live with the consequences of that decision.

So I'm trying to figure this out, but let's be real, Myspace is a public platform. If you post something on it, you have to accept that people will see it. That includes school officials, whether they're doing it under the school's name or not. They can access it from home, and in my opinion, if it means preventing a school shooting and saving lives, that's perfectly fine. I think it's the school's responsibility to ensure the safety of its students.

If school officials go on the internet to see if students are doing things they shouldn't be, like drinking or smoking, it feels like an invasion of privacy. But if it leads to making the school a better and safer place, I don't think that's an invasion at all. It's like when they do random checks to catch students doing something they shouldn't be doing, but that's a different story.

I feel like posting something on Myspace and not expecting to get in trouble is unrealistic. Everything can be found online, and it can come back to haunt you. If you post something as a college student, it can follow you for the rest of your life. Once it's on the internet, it's there forever.

I'm not saying I think it's okay for school officials to go on the internet just to catch students, but if they have a reason to do so, like to make the school a safer place, then that's a different story. It's like when parents drop off their kids at school, they expect it to be a safe place. I've talked to a teacher about this, and they said that's exactly why they monitor online activity.

They had to do lockdown drills and stuff because of the Columbine incident. They were just trying to prevent anything bad from happening. In this case, school officials were doing the same thing - making the school a safer place by preventing a potential school shooting. That's all I'm saying.

Okay, I've been thinking a lot about the whole thing. To be honest, I was initially all for it after 9/11 because it was a personal issue for me. I had strong feelings and wanted to do something, but now I'm not so sure. I think we rushed into it without thinking about the long-term consequences. We just kind of went in without a clear plan and, in my opinion, it backfired. Honestly, I was all for it at first, but my feelings have changed. I don't think we accomplished anything by being there. I think the people in that region are too busy fighting each other to focus on fighting us too. It's hard for me to care about what's going on over there because of how they seem to be handling things. It's almost like they're not even human in the way they go to war. They just can't seem to work together, and that's why I don't think we should be there.

I think we went in unprepared and didn't know what we were getting ourselves into. War is a completely different experience for them than for us. They're not looking to improve their country; they're just trying to get rid of us. I think we should just leave and be done with it. We were initially driven by emotions and a desire for revenge, but I don't think we were thinking rationally about the potential consequences. We were more hyped up than focused on creating a solution.

I understand why President Bush made the decision to declare war on Iraq at the time, but I'm not sure we had a choice. However, I do think we could have come up with a better plan and been more united in our goals. We didn't seem to know what we were doing or what we wanted to achieve, and that made things worse. I don't think we're the right people to change them; they've been that way for a long time, and it's not going to change overnight. I don't think we're making enough progress, and it's pointless to stay there any longer. Once we leave, I think it will just collapse, and we can't stay forever. I think we're just hurting ourselves by staying. That's my honest opinion.
